page.title: Additional Support Needs Tribunals for Scotland

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} The '''Additional Support Needs Tribunals for Scotland''' ('''ASNTS''') was a tribunal which considered appeals made against decisions of [[Local authorities of Scotland|local authorities]] regarding the provision of educational support.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fifedirect.org.uk/topics/index.cfm?fuseaction=page.display&p2sid=5BF0D8DB-E2F9-AED2-F94A270DDF4BDCBA&themeid=2B4D39FB-1CC4-E06A-5201AAA15FE8C653|title=Supporting children in school - ASN Tribunals| publisher=Fife Council |language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zd_sCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT188&dq=%22additional+support+needs+tribunals+for+scotland%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi__qa98_LbAhUqzIMKHdFRD4U4ChDoAQg0MAI#v=onepage&q=%22additional%20support%20needs%20tribunals%20for%20scotland%22&f=false|title=Resolving Disputes about Educational Provision: A Comparative Perspective on Special Educational Needs|last=Harris|first=Neville|last2=Riddell|first2=Sheila|date=2016-04-08|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317064954|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5gMyBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA54&dq=additional+support+needs+tribunals+for+scotland&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjaxtbQ8vLbAhWYxIMKHUwxDWUQ6AEISzAH#v=onepage&q=additional%20support%20needs%20tribunals%20for%20scotland&f=false|title=Protecting the Rights of People with Autism in the Fields of Education and Employment: International, European and National Perspectives|last=Fina|first=Valentina Della|last2=Cera|first2=Rachele|date=2015-03-09|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319137919|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lr3MCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT77&dq=additional+support+needs+tribunals+for+scotland&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjaxtbQ8vLbAhWYxIMKHUwxDWUQ6AEIRTAG#v=onepage&q=additional%20support%20needs%20tribunals%20for%20scotland&f=false|title=Special Educational Needs and Disability: The Basics|last=Wearmouth|first=Janice|date=2015-10-23|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317382249|language=en}}</ref>
==History== Prior to the tribunal, cases were previously heard in the [[sheriff court]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1002392.aspx#.WzMf1qknbdc |title=President for new learning support tribunal |work=The Journal |publisher=Law Society of Scotland |date=24 October 2005 |accessdate=27 June 2018}}</ref> The tribunals were established in November 2005 by the [[Education (Additional Support for Learning) (Scotland) Act 2004]]. By 2006 the panels were ready to hear cases.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.journalonline.co.uk/Magazine/51-2/1002707.aspx |title=A welcome addition |first=Stephanie |last=Carr |work=The Journal |publisher=Law Society of Scotland |date=13 February 2006 |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> The tribunals dealt with disputes concerning pupils with additional support needs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13157819.Parents_call_for_a_tribunal_to_handle_education_complaints/ |title=Parents call for a tribunal to handle educational complaints |first=Andrew |last=Denholm |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow) |The Herald]] |date=29 April 2014 |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> The remit of the tribunals included placing requests to special schools, transition and disability discrimination.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/14227378.More_must_be_done_to_support_autistic_children_in_mainstream_school__says_education_solicitor/ |title=More must be done to support autistic children in mainstream school, says education solicitor |first=Linzi |last=Watson |work=The Herald |location=Glasgow |date=25 January 2016 |accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> In 2010 the [[Scottish Government]] consulted on secondary legislation that could enable the tribunal to hear disability claims cases that related to school education.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1008366.aspx#.WzMsyKknajQ |title=Tribunals to hear education discrimination claims |work=The Journal |publisher=Law Society of Scotland |date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2018}}</ref>
Its functions were transferred to the Health and Education Chamber of the First-tier Tribunal for Scotland in January 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thenational.scot/news/15597777.Devolved_and_reserved_tribunals_to_be_brought_under_one_roof_in_Glasgow_city_centre/|title=Devolved and reserved tribunals to be brought under one roof in Glasgow city centre|website=The National| |date=15 October 2017 |first=Martin |last=Hannan |language=en-UK|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scottishlegal.com/article/new-chambers-first-tier-tribunal-scotland |work=Scottish Legal News|title=New chambers for First-tier Tribunal for Scotland|date=12 January 2018|language=en-UK|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.healthandeducationchamber.scot/additional-support-needs/12|title=Additional Support Needs |publisher= First-tier Tribunal for Scotland (Health and Education Chamber) |language=en|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref> Decisions of the ASNTS could be appealed to the [[Inner House of the Court of Session]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scottishlegal.com/article/council-breached-equality-act-failures-supporting-autistic-childs-return-education|title=Council breached Equality Act over failures in supporting autistic child’s return to education |work=Scottish Legal News|date=26 March 2018|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-UK}}</ref> The caseloads for the ASNTS had risen because of the "inadequate" provision for special-needs students in mainstream education, one academic said.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tes.com/news/sharp-rise-special-needs-tribunal-cases-blamed-inadequate-provision-mainstream-schools|title=Sharp rise in special needs tribunal cases blamed on 'inadequate' provision in mainstream schools |first=Emma |last=Seith |date=24 April 2018 |work= Tes News |language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-27|quote=Growing numbers of parents are battling to send their children away to residential special schools due to the "inadequate" provision in mainstream education, a leading academic has warned.}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20161105134129/http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/Images/Revised%20Guide%20December%202008a_tcm4-464411.pdf A User’s guide] on Education Scotland
{{Tribunals of the Scottish Government}}
[[Category:Tribunals of the Scottish Government]] [[Category:Health law in Scotland]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 2005]] [[Category:Courts and tribunals established in 2005]]

'''CBHS Health Fund''' is an Australian private health insurance company founded on January 1, 1951 by the [[Commonwealth Bank of Australia]] (CBA) to provide insurance to its employees. Membership was expanded in August 1996 to include former employees.
==Description== The organization changed its name to the CBHS Friendly Society that same year, and it became independent of the bank. The name was changed again in 2007 to CBHS Health Fund Limited, and coverage was offered to family members of current and former employees starting in 2007. Contractors and franchise holders of CBA Group became eligible for membership in 2014. CBHS is a member of Private Healthcare Australia, formerly known as the Australian Health Insurance Association.
In 2016, data for CBHS customers was stolen from a marketing and member communications contractor.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itnews.com.au/news/attackers-exploiting-cba-health-fund-data-breach-439154|title=Attackers exploiting CBA health fund data breach|last=Coyne|first=Allie|date=11 October 2016|work=itnews|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-13/hackers-steal-personal-information-from-bank-health-fund/7929542|title=Hackers steal personal information from Commonwealth Bank's health fund|last=Sturmer|first=Jake|date=13 October 2016|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, CBHS introduced a [[mobile app]] which can be downloaded from Google and Apple stores.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cbhs.com.au}}
[[Category:Health insurance in Australia]] [[Category:Commonwealth Bank]]] [[Category:Health insurance companies]] [[Category:Financial services companies established in 1951]] [[Category:1951 establishments in Australia]]

{{pp-move-vandalism|small=yes}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{featured article}} {| class="infobox" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse; width:240px;" |- | colspan=2 style="background: #f0f0f0; font-weight: bolder; text-align: center;" | '''Chew Valley Lake''' |- | colspan=2 style="text-align: center; background: white;" | <!-- Missing image removed: [[Image:Keynsham - Bath and North East Somerset dot.png|200px]] --> |- | style="width:50%;"| Governing body | style="width:50%;"| [[Bristol Water]] |- | style="width:50%;"| SSSI Ref | style="width:50%;"| 1001346 |- | style="width:50%;"| SPA Code | style="width:50%;"| UK9010041 |} {{Infobox lake | name = Chew Valley Lake | image = | caption = | image_bathymetry = Chew Valley Lake map.PNG | caption_bathymetry = Map | alt=Map of the lake showing the names of bays and inlets | location = [[Somerset]] | coords = {{coord|51|20|4.92|N|2|37|4.92|W|type:waterbody_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | lake_type = Reservoir | inflow = [[River Chew]] | outflow = [[River Chew]] | catchment = {{convert|14000|acre|km2|abbr=on}} | basin_countries = United Kingdom | length = | width = | area = {{convert|1200|acre|km2|abbr=on}} | depth = {{convert|14|ft|abbr=on}} | max-depth = {{convert|37|ft|abbr=on}} | volume = {{convert|4500000000|impgal|km3|abbr=on}} | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = Denny Island | cities = }} '''Chew Valley Lake''' ({{gbmapping|ST5659}}) is a large [[reservoir (water)|reservoir]] in the [[Chew Valley]], [[Somerset]], [[England]], and the fifth-largest artificial lake in the United Kingdom (the largest in south-west England), with an area of 1,200 acres (4.9 km²). The lake, created in the early 1950s and opened by [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] in 1956, provides much of the [[drinking water]] for the city of [[Bristol]] and surrounding area, taking its supply from the [[Mendip Hills]]. Some of the water from the lake is used to maintain the flow in the [[River Chew]].
Before the lake was created, archaeological investigations were carried out that showed evidence of occupation since [[Neolithic]] times and included [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] artefacts. The lake is an important site for wildlife and has been designated a [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSI) and a [[Special Protection Area]] (SPA). It is a national centre for [[birdwatching]], with over 260 species recorded. The lake has indigenous and migrant water birds throughout the year, and two nature trails have been created. The [[flora (plants)|flora]] and [[fauna (animals)|fauna]] provide [[habitat (ecology)|habitats]] for some less common plants and insects.
Some restricted use for recreational activities is permitted by the owner, [[Bristol Water]], including [[dinghy sailing]] and fishing, primarily for [[trout]].
== Location == Chew Valley Lake is in the [[Chew Valley]] at the northern edge of the [[Mendip Hills]], surrounded by meadows and woods and close to the villages of [[Chew Stoke]], [[Chew Magna]] and [[Bishop Sutton]]. When it was built in the 1950s, its 1,200 acres (4.9 km²) were flooded with 4,500 million imperial gallons (20,000,000 m³) of water from the Mendip hills,<ref name="bw">{{cite web|url=http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/chewIndex.asp |title=Chew Valley Introduction |publisher=Bristol Water |accessdate=14 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706120237/http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/chewIndex.asp |archivedate= 6 July 2008 |df= }}</ref> with a catchment area of 14,000 acres (57 km²).<ref name=riverchew>{{cite web|title=Chew Valley Lake |url=http://www.riverchew.co.uk/chew_valley_lake.htm |website=River Chew |publisher=Jason Allen |accessdate=23 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227161748/http://www.riverchew.co.uk/chew_valley_lake.htm |archivedate=27 December 2014 |df= }}</ref> It is shallow, with an average depth of 14 ft (4 m) at top level and a maximum depth of just 37 ft (11 m). It is fed by small rivers, and it flows into the [[River Chew]] for 17 miles (27 km) before it joins the [[River Avon, Bristol|Avon]] to head out to sea. The deepest part is near the dam and the outlet tower, where the steeply sloping shores of Walley Bank and the north shore result in depths of up to 20 ft (6 m).<ref name=riverchew/> "Denny Island", above the surface throughout the year, is wooded and provides a habitat for wildlife.
The lake is owned and operated by Bristol Water, which created it in 1956 when the demand became too large for nearby [[Blagdon Lake]]. Working with the [[Avon Wildlife Trust]], [[Somerset Wildlife Trust]] and other environmental groups, Bristol Water has encouraged various species of birds and plants, and created a venue for visitors.<ref name="bw"/>
It has two landscaped picnic areas. Facilities include a [[tea shop]], with indoor and outdoor seating areas with a view of the lake, and information centre. There are a souvenir shop and small art gallery<ref>{{cite web|title=Art Gallery |url=http://www.chewvalleyart.co.uk/ |accessdate=4 January 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060102212053/http://www.chewvalleyart.co.uk/ |archivedate= 2 January 2006 |df= }}</ref> and two nature trails. The Grebe Trail<ref>{{cite web|title=Grebe Nature Trail |work=Bristol Water Leisure Guide |url=http://www.bristol-water.co.uk/leisure/chewNature-grebe.asp |accessdate=3 January 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821003315/http://www.bristol-water.co.uk/leisure/chewNature-grebe.asp |archivedate=21 August 2008 |df= }}</ref> is a hard-surfaced, all-weather path suitable for pedestrians, pushchairs and wheelchairs and covers a circuit 0.75 miles (1.2 km) long, starting and finishing at the wooded picnic area. The Bittern Trail<ref>{{cite web|title=Bittern Nature Trail |work=Bristol Water Leisure Guide |url=http://www.bristol-water.co.uk/leisure/chewNature-bittern.asp |accessdate=3 January 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827162237/http://www.bristol-water.co.uk/leisure/chewNature-bittern.asp |archivedate=27 August 2008 |df= }}</ref> is reached from the Grebe Trail by the footbridge over Hollow Brook. The grassy path is often waterlogged in winter, but there is a boardwalk over a short section. The trail runs along the east shore, visits an open bird hide and returns to the footbridge, making a 1-mile (1.5-kilometre) circuit. Bristol Water imposes conditions on visitors, particularly related to the areas where dogs are allowed.
== Access and transportation == [[File:Wodford Lodge, Chew Valley Lake.jpg|thumb|Woodford Lodge and part of the sailing club]] Access to the waterside is restricted in places to reduce the disruption to wildlife. Paths around the lake are generally flat and, where paths are surfaced, wheelchair access is possible.
Visitors are officially invited to use public transport, but overwhelmingly arrive by private car, encouraged by the provision of parking spaces. The "Chew Valley Explorer" bus route 672/674 provides access.<ref>{{cite web | title=Changes to Chew Valley Explorer | work=Evening Post | publisher=This is Bristol | url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/Changes-Chew-Valley-Explorer/article-1009122-detail/article.html | accessdate=9 April 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130114015703/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/Changes-Chew-Valley-Explorer/article-1009122-detail/article.html | archivedate=14 January 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2002 a 1.9-mile (3-kilometre) safe cycle route, the Chew Lake West Green Route, was opened along the B3114 on the western part of the lake. It forms part of the [[Padstow]] to [[Bristol]] West Country Way, [[National Cycle Network]] [[NCR 3|Route 3]]. It has all-weather surfacing, providing a smooth off-road facility for ramblers, mobility-challenged visitors and cyclists of all abilities. It was funded by [[Bath and North East Somerset]] Council with the support of [[Sustrans]] and the Chew Valley Recreational Trail Association. Minor roads around the lake are also frequently used by cyclists.
[[Bristol Airport]] is approximately 10 miles (15 km) away. The nearest major road is the [[A368 road|A368]], which runs along the southern edge of the lake and provides access from [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] and [[Weston super Mare]]. The [[A37 road|A37]] and [[A38 road|A38]] are slightly further away, providing access from [[Bristol]]. Car parking is available at the visitor centre and Woodford Lodge, for which a charge is made, and a small amount of parking is available at points around the lake; some of these are restricted to those with fishing permits.
== History == [[Image:Chewvalleylakeplaque.JPG|left|thumb|alt=plague with text commemorating the visit of Queen Elixabeth II|Plaque unveiled by Queen Elizabeth II in 1956]]The area the lake covers was once rich farmland. Farms and houses had to be removed before the land was flooded, and old roads, hedgerows and tree stumps can reappear when dry summers cause the level of the lake to drop. Prior to the flooding of the [[reservoir (water)|reservoir]], [[archaeology|archaeological]] [[excavation (archaeology)|excavations]] were carried out by [[Philip Rahtz]] and [[Ernest Greenfield]] employed by the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]], from 1953 to 1955. The excavations found evidence of people belonging to the consecutive periods known as [[Upper Palaeolithic]], [[Mesolithic]] and [[Neolithic]] (Old, Middle and New [[Stone Age]]), [[Bronze Age]] and [[Iron Age]], including implements such as stone knives, [[flint]] blades and the head of a [[mace (bludgeon)|mace]], along with buildings and graves.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dunning |first=Robert |title=A History of Somerset |year=1983 |publisher=Phillimore & Co |location=Chichester |isbn=0-85033-461-6 }}</ref> The [[Artifact (archaeology)|artefacts]] from this period are held at [[Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery]].<ref name="ross">{{cite book | author = Ross, Lesley (Ed.)| year = 2004 | title = Before the Lake: Memories of the Chew Valley | publisher = The Harptree Historic Society | isbn=0-9548832-0-9 }}</ref> Further evidence of Neolithic and Bronze Age occupation is provided by the archaeological survey of the [[Mendip Hills]] Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty.<ref name=survey>{{cite web|title=Mendip Hills An Archaeological Survey of the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty |work=Somerset County Council Archaeological Projects |url=http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/HES_MendipAONB.pdf |accessdate=16 January 2011 |format=PDF |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516154619/http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/HES_MendipAONB.pdf |archivedate=16 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> Excavations have also uncovered Roman remains, indicating agricultural and industrial activity from the second half of the first century to third century AD. The finds included a [[Roman villa|villa]] at Chew Park<ref name=survey/> where wooden writing tablets (the first in the UK) with [[ink]] writing were found. The tablets were sent to the [[British Museum]], but other Roman material is on display at the Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery with the lake's other historical artefacts.<ref name="ross" />
Further excavations around the village of Moreton, which has now been totally submerged, found evidence of a thriving community in [[medieval]] times and possibly the remains of the [[Nunnery]] of Santa Cruz.<ref>{{cite book | author = Hucker, Ernest| year = 1997 | title = Chew Stoke Recalled in Old Photographs|publisher = Ernest Hucker|id = }}</ref> During the [[Middle Ages]] farming was the most important activity in the area covered by the lake, supported by four [[flour mill]]s powered by the River Chew. Stratford Mill was demolished and re-erected in the grounds of [[Blaise Castle]] Museum, in north-west Bristol. The largest settlement was Moreton, which is listed in the [[Domesday Book]] and survived until the flooding of the lake, when the remains of the Moreton Cross were moved to [[Chew Stoke]] Parish Church. There is evidence of [[Limekiln|lime kilns]], which were used in the production of mortar for the construction of local churches. Farming, both [[arable land|arable]] and [[dairy farming|dairy]], continued until the flooding of the lake, with most households also keeping pigs. There were [[orchard]]s for fruit production, including apples, pears and [[plum]]s.<ref name="ross" /> Moreton was also the site of [[gunpowder]] mill in the 18th century.<ref name=body>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=__Q6AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT100&lpg=PT100&dq=Littleton+gunpowder&source=bl&ots=oyK7d0gtCF&sig=BYx1b5btgcaZ1MVx4wF1T_CsDpM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3wrmmmZ3KAhVGPxQKHdv0ClgQ6AEIQTAG#v=onepage&q=Littleton%20gunpowder&f=false|last1=Body|first1=Geoffrey|title=The A-Z of Curious Somerset|date=2013|publisher=The History Press|isbn=9780752493299|pages=84–87}}</ref>
=== Reservoir === [[Image:CVLdam.JPG|thumb|744px|center|alt=Photograph showing the white coloured dam running horizontally across the picture with water and vegetation in the foreground and hills behind|Chew Valley Lake dam]] [[Image:Chewpumpingstation.JPG|thumb|alt=White concrete single story building, with vegetation around|Pumping Station]] Plans for the building of the reservoir were under discussion before the [[Second World War]], and an [[Act of Parliament]] submitted by the Bristol Waterworks Company was passed in 1939. Following this, farms were bought by the company and farmed by the previous owners as tenancies. Farms and buildings still remaining in private hands were acquired by [[compulsory purchase]]. The sanction for construction was given in 1949 and the contract awarded to A.E. Farr, who employed 300 people on the site. The main dam was stabilised by injecting concrete into the cracks in the [[bedrock]]. The core of the dam was made of [[puddling (engineering)|puddled]] [[clay]] mixed with [[sand]]. This was the first time the gain in strength brought about by the use of sand drains had been quantified.<ref>{{cite book | author = Skempton, A.W. | year = 1984 | title = Selected Papers on Soil Mechanics|publisher = Thomas Telford|isbn=0-7277-0205-X}}</ref> The lake was inaugurated by [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]], accompanied by [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]], with the unveiling of a commemorative stone and plaque, which can be seen from the dam, on 17 April 1956, although it was not full until 25 February 1958.<ref name="ross" /> Flowers were presented to the Queen at the opening of Chew Valley Lake by Judith Blair Brown, daughter of Kennedy Brown, who worked at Bristol Water Works at the time of construction of the lake.
During the [[Chew Stoke flood of 1968|storm of 10 July 1968]], the lake gained an extra 471 million imperial gallons (2,140,000 m³) and rose 19 inches (480 mm) in under 12 hours. At one point worried [[Bristol City Police|Bristol police]] issued a warning that the dam might not hold, prompting localised evacuation of populated valley areas downstream including [[Pensford]] and [[Keynsham]].<ref name="ea">{{cite book|last=Richley|first=Rob|title=The Chew Valley floods of 1968|publisher=Environment Agency|location=Exeter|date=June 2008}}</ref>
== Ecology == [[Image:Herriotts06-04.jpg|thumb|center|alt=photograph of the lake showing a road crossing via a causeway at Herriots Bridge. It is surrounded by green vegetation with hills in the distance|744px|Herriot's Bridge]]
The lake is designated a [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSI)<ref>{{cite web|title=Chew Valley Lake |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002553.pdf |website=SSSI Citation |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924131553/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002553.pdf |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df= }}</ref> and a [[Special Protection Area]] (SPA) (Site Code: UK9010041) largely because of the diversity of species and habitats. Providing further protection, much of the area around the lake also falls within the [[Mendip Hills]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] (AONB).
The lake appears to have a higher sedimentation rate than would be expected in other similar reservoirs, being in the region of 100–150 t.km<sup>−2</sup>.yr<sup>−1</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wilson|first1=R.S.|first2=M. A. |last2=Sleigh |first3=T. R. A. |last3=Maxwell |first4=G. |last4=Mance|first5= R. A.|last5= Milne|year=1974|title=Physical and chemical aspects of Chew Valley and Blagdon Lakes, two eutrophic reservoirs in North Somerset, England|journal=Freshwater Biology|volume=5|issue=4|pages=357–377|url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119654163/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2427.1975.tb01760.x}}</ref>
=== Geology === The main geological outcrops around the lake are [[mudstone]], largely consisting of red [[siltstone]] resulting in the underlying characteristic of the gently rolling valley landscape. Bands of [[sandstone]] from the [[Triassic]] period contribute to the undulating character of the area. There are also more recent [[alluvial]] deposits beside the course of the River Chew.<ref name="banes">{{cite web|title=Area 2: Chew Valley |url=http://www.bathnes.gov.uk/sites/default/files/rural_landscapes_-_chapter_7.pdf |publisher=Bath and North East Somerset |pages=26–29 |accessdate=23 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202180741/http://www.bathnes.gov.uk/sites/default/files/rural_landscapes_-_chapter_7.pdf |archivedate= 2 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
=== Birds === [[Image:Mallard in flight.jpg|alt=Bird with wings forward. Yellow bill, green head with white collar, brown body with blue wing feathers and orange feet.|thumb|Drake in flight on Chew Valley Lake]] Over 260 species of birds have been recorded at Chew,<ref>{{cite web |title=Birdwatching |url=http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/birdwatching-information.asp |publisher=Bristol Water |accessdate=12 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716064532/http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/birdwatching-information.asp |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> an internationally important site for wintering and migrating wildfowl. From late July to February, up to 4,000 [[duck]]s (Anatidae) of twelve different species may be present, including internationally important numbers of [[northern shoveler]] (''Anas clypeata'') and [[gadwall]] (''Anas strepera''). Up to 600 [[great crested grebe]]s (''Podiceps cristatus'') gather to moult on the lake in autumn.<ref name="cvlbirding">{{cite web|title=Chew Valley Lake Birding |url=http://www.cvlbirding.co.uk/ |accessdate=3 January 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051230173501/http://www.cvlbirding.co.uk/ |archivedate=30 December 2005 |df= }}</ref> Data on bird species and their numbers on the lake, dating back to the first "[[Bird ringing|ringing]]" in 1964, is available from the Chew Valley Ringing Station.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chew Valley Ringing Station |url=http://www.chewvalleyringingstation.co.uk/ |accessdate=6 January 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130185750/http://www.chewvalleyringingstation.co.uk/ |archivedate=30 January 2010 |df= }}</ref>
Numerous other birds can be seen, especially during the spring and autumn [[bird migration|migration]]. [[Sand martin]]s (''Riparia riparia'') arrive early and can usually be seen hawking over the water for insects in the second or third week of March. Flocks of [[titmouse|tits]] (Paridae), [[Hirundinidae|swallows]] (Hirundinidae) and [[terns]] (Sternidae) can regularly be seen. Waders, such as [[northern lapwing|lapwings]] (''Vanellus vanellus''), [[dunlin]] (''Calidris alpina'') and [[common snipe]] (''Gallinago gallinago''), are attracted to the muddy shores if the water level drops in autumn. By midwinter up to 55,000 [[gull]]s, mostly [[black-headed gull]] (''Chroicocephalus ridibundus'') and [[common gull]] (''Larus canus''), may be roosting. Good numbers of [[reed warbler]]s (''Acrocephalus scirpaceus'') and [[sedge warbler]]s (''A. schoenobaenus'') nest in the fringing reeds, along with [[grebes]] (Podicipedidae) and [[Eurasian coot]]s (''Fulica atra'').<ref name="cvlbirding" />
Much of the management work carried out in the nature reserve is aimed at encouraging ducks to breed, and small numbers of [[tufted duck]] (''Aythya fuligula''), [[common pochard]] (''Aythya ferina''), [[common shelduck]] (''Tadorna tadorna'') and [[gadwall]] raise broods most years. Recent breeding successes also include [[water rail]] (''Rallus aquaticus'') and [[Cetti's warbler]] (''Cettia cetti'').<ref name="cvlbirding" />
A wetland reserve has been created at Heron's Green Pool on the opposite side of the causeway to the lake. A shallow pool fringed with [[Cyperaceae|sedges]] (Cyperaceae), [[Juncaceae|rushes]] (Juncaceae) and [[Calamagrostis|reedgrasses]] (''Calamagrostis'') and surrounded by lightly grazed, rough [[grassland]] may also prove attractive to snipe and lapwings.
=== Fish === In late summer large shoals of [[common roach|roach]] (''Rutilus rutilus'') and [[perch]] (''Perca fluviatilis'') fry congregate around the margins and weed beds, which are predated by the brown trout ([[Salmo trutta fario|''Salmo trutta'' morpha ''fario'']]) and [[rainbow trout]] (''Oncorhynchus mykiss'').<ref name="fishing">{{cite web | title=Fishing information] | work=Bristol Waters | url=http://eis.bris.ac.uk/~cckhrb/BW/chew.htm | accessdate=4 January 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051228193850/http://eis.bris.ac.uk/~cckhrb/BW/chew.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 28 December 2005}}</ref> Chew Valley also holds a large population of [[northern pike|pike]] (''Esox lucius''), and fishing for these is permitted at certain times of the year.
=== Insects === [[Chironomidae|Aquatic midges]] (Chironomidae) provide the highest proportion of the fly life of the lake. The [[trout]] (Salmonidae) will feed at the surface on these and [[Corixidae|water boatmen]] (Corixidae), and below the surface on the [[caddisfly]] (Trichoptera) [[larva]]e and [[pupa]]e; they will also take the adult caddisflies when they emerge. Other aquatic fauna including ''[[daphnia]]'' and [[snail]]s are also found in the lake.<ref name="awt">{{cite web|title=Chew Valley Lake Information |work=Avon Wildlife Trust |url=http://www.avonwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/chew_valley.htm |accessdate=3 January 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031000510/http://www.avonwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/chew_valley.htm |archivedate=31 October 2010 |df= }}</ref> Large populations of [[dragonflies]], including [[migrant hawker]] (''Aeshna mixta'') and significant numbers of [[ruddy darter]] (''Sympetrum sanguineum''), occur at the lake. Eleven species of wainscot [[moth]] make their home in the reed beds, including the nationally local brown-veined wainscot (''Archanara dissoluta''), twin-spotted wainscot (''Archanara geminipuncta'') and silky wainscot (''Chilodes maritimus'').<ref name="cvlbirding"/>
=== Vegetation === The lake is surrounded with fringing [[reedbed]]s, [[carr (fen)|carr woodland]] and [[grassland]], which are managed by [[Bristol Water]]. The water conditions are [[eutrophic]] with run off from local fields and streams. Open-water plant communities are rather sparse, largely comprising [[Potamogeton|fennel pondweed]] (''Potamogeton pectinatus''), [[Potamogeton|lesser pondweed]] (''Potamogeton pusillus''), [[Groenlandia|opposite-leaved pondweed]] (''Groenlandia densa'') and [[Ranunculus|water-crowfoot]] (''Ranunculus spp.''). On neutral soils around the reservoir, [[pepper-saxifrage]] (''Silaum silaus''), [[saxifrage|burnet-saxifrage]] (''Pimpinella saxifraga'') and [[scabious|devil's-bit scabious]] (''Succisa pratensis'') occur, and on calcareous soils fairy [[flax]] (''Linum catharticum''), [[Cirsium|dwarf thistle]] (''Cirsium acaule'') and [[salad burnet]] (''Sanguisorba minor'' subspecies ''minor'') are found.<ref name="awt" />
The small and medium-sized fields around the lake are generally bounded by hedges and occasionally by tree belts and woodland, some of which date back to the most evident period of enclosure of earlier open fields which took place in the late medieval period. Mature [[oak]] (''Quercus'') and [[ash tree|ash]] (''Fraxinus excelsior'') trees are characteristic of the area with occasional groups of [[Scots pine]] (''Pinus sylvestris'') and [[chestnut]]s (''Castanea sativa''). Many [[elm]] (''Ulmus'') trees have been lost in this area, and dead/dying elms are also evident in the surrounding landscape.<ref name="banes" />
Four areas of woodland containing 157 trees has been planted by The Life for a Life Charity around the lake on the Restaurant side, for the cremated remains of loved ones to be placed beneath them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lifeforalife.org.uk/locations/find?site=16 |title=Chew Valley Lake |publisher=Life for a Life |accessdate=23 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715142045/http://www.lifeforalife.org.uk/locations/find?site=16 |archivedate=15 July 2015 |df= }}</ref> These forests contain [[Scots pine]] (''Pinus sylvestris''), [[English oak]] (''Quercus robur''), [[rowan]] (''Sorbus aucuparia'') and the [[silver birch]] (''Betula pendula'').
== Leisure use == The lake is used for a wide variety of leisure pursuits.
=== Birdwatching === [[Image:Pic herriots pool.jpg|thumb|alt=Expanse of water with white birds. Trees and hills in the background|Birds on Chew Valley Lake taken from Herriott's Bridge]]
During 2005–2006 Bristol Water started restoring two artificial islands. These are intended to provide safe nesting and roosting sites for a range of wildfowl. Permits to enter the reservoir enclosure and to use the access roads, paths and bird hides are available (for a fee) only to members of ornithological and naturalist societies recognised by Bristol Water. They can be obtained from Woodford Lodge and include conditions of use imposed by the owners.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/birdwatching-information.asp |title=Birdwatching |publisher=Bristol Water |accessdate=21 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090828052653/http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/birdwatching-information.asp |archivedate=28 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Sailing === [[File:Sailing on Chew Valley Lake.webm|thumb|Boats sailing on the lake]] Chew Valley Lake Sailing Club has a sailing area, approximately 1.9 miles (3 km) long, for [[dinghy sailing]]. The lake is divided into two areas: a restricted summer area which is available during the fishing season (mid-March to mid-October), and the full area which can be used throughout the winter and on Sunday afternoons. The sailing area is marked out by lines of small white buoys. Racing marks are red buoys with flags, although large inflatable marks are used of open events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chewvalleysailing.org.uk/lake-plan |title=Lake plan |publisher=Chew Valley Sailing Club |accessdate=17 September 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624051431/http://www.chewvalleysailing.org.uk/lake-plan |archivedate=24 June 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The club can cater for fleets of over one hundred boats and it hosts large national events. Normal club racing has fleet starts for the following dinghy classes: [[Flying Fifteen (keelboat)]], [[Laser (dinghy)]], [[Solo (dinghy)]] and [[Topper (dinghy)]] as well as a handicap fleet run under the [[Portsmouth yardstick]] scheme. Five slipways enable easy launching. Off the water, the clubhouse facilities include large changing rooms, hot showers, hot food at the weekends, a bar and terrace overlooking the lake. The club caters for disabled people with facilities on both floors and a lift. [[Royal Yachting Association]] sailing courses are held at the club for members including race training, youth training, powerboat training, race officer training as well as more informal training run within each fleet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chewvalleysailing.org.uk/training/other-training |title=RYA Training |publisher=Chew Valley Sailing Club |accessdate=17 September 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624052001/http://www.chewvalleysailing.org.uk/training/other-training |archivedate=24 June 2010 |df= }}</ref>
=== Fishing === Seasonal day and afternoon bank fishing permits are available at Woodford Lodge. The restrictions imposed by Bristol Water mean that no fishing is allowed from the dams or stone [[Dike (construction)|embankments]], the sailing club, in front of Stratford bird hide, in front of the [[picnic]] areas and in the [[nature reserve]]. There is a fleet of 32 motor boats for hire to fish.<ref name="fishing" />

revision.text:
'''Circumsporozoite protein''' (CSP) is a secreted [[protein]] of the [[sporozoite]] stage of the [[malaria]] parasite (''[[Plasmodium]]'' sp.) and is the [[antigen]]ic target of [[RTS,S]], a pre-erythrocytic malaria vaccine currently undergoing clinical trials.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Porter|first=Michael|author2=Jennifer Nicki |author3=Christopher Pool |title=Transgenic Parasites Stably Expressing Full-Length Plasmodium falciparum Circumsporozoite Protein as a Model for Vaccine Down-Selection in Mice Using Sterile Protection as an Endpoint|journal=Clinical and Vaccine Immunology|date=June 2013|volume=20|issue=6|pages=803–810|url=http://cvi.asm.org/content/20/6/803.long|doi=10.1128/cvi.00066-13|pmc=3675977}}</ref> The amino-acid sequence of CSP consists of an immunodominant central repeat region flanked by conserved motifs at the [[N-terminus|N-]] and [[C-terminus|C-]] termini that are implicated in protein processing as the parasite travels from the mosquito to the mammalian vector.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Aldrich|first=Cassandra|author2=Alessandro Magini |author3=Carla Emiliani |title=Roles of the Amino Terminal Region and Repeat Region of the Plasmodium berghei Circumsporozoite Protein in Parasite Infectivity|journal=PLOS ONE|date=February 2012|volume=7|issue=2|url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0032524|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0032524|pages=e32524|pmid=22393411|pmc=3290588}}</ref>
The structure and function of CSP is highly conserved across the various strains of malaria that infect humans, non-human primates and rodents. It can first be detected in large quantities as sporozoites are forming within [[oocyst]]s residing in the midgut walls of infected mosquitoes. Upon egression from mature oocysts, sporozoites begin migrating to the salivary glands, and CSP is known to be an important mediator of this process. Additionally, CSP is involved in [[hepatocyte]] binding in the mammalian host. Here, the N-terminus and central repeat region initially facilitate parasite binding.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rathore|first=Dharmendar|author2=John B. Sacci |author3=Patricia de la Vega |author4=Thomas F. McCutchan |title=Binding and Invasion of Liver Cells by ''Plasmodium falciparum'' Sporozoites|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|date=March 2002|volume=277|issue=9|pages=7092–7098|url=http://www.jbc.org/content/277/9/7092.abstract?ijkey=f74c5acb4519bd34e1d6a0fbc27629bc7dcb10cc&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha |doi=10.1074/jbc.m106862200}}</ref> On the hepatocyte surface [[proteolytic cleavage]] at region 1 of the N-terminus exposes the adhesive domain of the C-terminus, thereby priming the parasites for invasion of the [[liver]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Coppi|first=Alida|author2=Consuelo Pinzon-Ortiz |author3=Christina Hunter |title=The Plasmodium circumsporozoite protein is proteolytically processed during cell invasion|journal=JEM|date=January 2005|volume=201|issue=1|pages=27–33|url=http://jem.rupress.org/content/201/1/27.full.pdf|doi=10.1084/jem.20040989|pmc=1995445}}</ref>
CSP is an approximately 42 [[Kilodalton|kD]] soluble protein and can readily be made using an ''[[E. coli]]'' [[expression system]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Malaria]] [[Category:Apicomplexan proteins]]

revision.text:
For Cumulative Learning in artificial intelligence, see [[Multi-task learning]]
Cumulative learning is the cognitive process by which we accumulate knowledge and abilities that serve as building blocks for subsequent cognitive development.<ref name="auto">{{cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-1-4419-1428-6_1660|title=Encyclopedia of the Sciences of Learning|first=JungMi|last=Lee|editor-first=Prof Dr Norbert M.|editor-last=Seel|date=1 January 2012|publisher=Springer US|pages=887–893|accessdate=3 June 2016|via=link.springer.com|doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-1428-6_1660}}</ref> A very simple example is the saying 'you can't run before you can walk'; the [[procedural memory]] built while learning to walk is necessary before one can start to learn to run. Pronouncing words is impossible without first learning to pronounce the vowels and consonants that make them up (hence babies' [[babbling]]).
This is an essential cognitive capacity, allowing prior development to produce new foundations for further cognitive development. Cumulative learning consolidates the knowledge one has obtained through experiences, allowing it to be reproduced and exploited for subsequent learning situations through cumulative interaction between prior knowledge and new information.<ref name="auto"/>
Arguably, all learning is cumulative learning, as all learning depends on previous learning<ref>Richey, Rita C. "The future role of Robert M. Gagne in instructional design." The Legacy of Robert M. Gagne (2000): 255-281.</ref> (except skills that are innate, such as breathing, swallowing, gripping etc).
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Learning]]
{{psychology-stub}}

The '''Dahl effect''' or Dahl concept is used in [[dentistry]] where a localized appliance or localized restoration is used to increase the available interocclusal space available for restorations. {{TOC limit|History=|Mode of action=}} == Method and concept == The Dahl Concept refers to the relative axial tooth movement that is observed when a localised appliance or localised restorations are placed in supra-occlusion and the occlusion re-establishes full arch contacts over a period of time. The effect works by a combination of intrusion (40%) of the anterior teeth in contact with the appliance and eruption (60%) of the unopposed posterior teeth. == History == In 1962, D. J. Anderson from [[Guy's Hospital|Guy’s Hospital Medical School]], described the idea of manipulating occlusion by inducing over-eruption. This was achieved by placing bite-raising caps on certain teeth in the arch and observing the changes in distances between other teeth of opposing arches.{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=D.J.|title=Tooth movement in experimental malocclusion|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0003-9969(62)90043-2|journal=Archives of Oral Biology|volume=7|issue=1|pages=7–15|doi=10.1016/0003-9969(62)90043-2}} However, in 1975, Bjørn L. Dahl from the Faculty of Dentistry of [[University of Oslo]] became the first author through a series of papers to report the successful use of the technique for the management of the worn dentition. Dahl, along with Olaf Krogstad and Kjell Karlsen, described this phenomenon where a [[Dahl appliance]] or anterior bite plane is used to increase the available interocclusal space available for restorations.{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=BJøRN L.|last2=Krogstad|first2=Olaf|last3=Karlsen|first3=Kjell|date=1975-07-01|title=An alternative treatment in cases with advanced localized attrition|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2842.1975.tb00914.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Oral Rehabilitation|language=en|volume=2|issue=3|pages=209–214|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2842.1975.tb00914.x|issn=1365-2842}} A male, 18 year old patient with heavy wear on the palatal aspect of his dentition and no interproximal contacts in the anterior teeth was the subject of the experiment. A removable cobalt chromium platform was worn, which covered the upper palatal surface of the anterior teeth, while being held in place by clasps in the canine and premolar region. The appliance was worn for 24 hours each day over a 12 month period except for cleaning after every meal. This caused the premolars and molars of the patient to be propped open with the anterior teeth occluding the appliance. == Clinical Application == The Dahl concept is commonly used when an increase in the [[interocclusal space]] is required together with an increase in [[occlusal vertical dimension]] ; for example when restoring a case of severe anterior [[tooth surface loss]].
Typically, restoring the worn anterior teeth with [[dental composite]] to the original proportions will result in an increase in OVD, with the posterior dentition held apart out of the [[occlusion (dentistry)|occlusion]]. Adaptation occurs over a period of some months: compensatory eruption of the posterior teeth will occur, together with some intrusion of the anterior teeth and potential growth of the [[alveolar bone]]. This will allow the posterior occlusion to reestablish at the new increased OVD, stabilizing the increased interocclusal space. Dentoalveolar tissues tend to compensate by remodelling when incisal/occlusal tooth surface loss has occurred to allow the teeth to regain a functional occlusion. A subsequent increase in the OVD with the Dahl approach could exceed the patient's tolerance and adaptive capacity. If the patient is unhappy with the height of their teeth and a Dahl approach cannot be tolerated then crown lengthening may be appropriate. == Dahl appliance == The original material used to construct Dahl's appliance was cobalt chromium. Now, many materials can be used to construct Dahl's appliance as long as the principles of technique are adhered to. A Dahl appliance should fulfil the following aims: * A thickness of material should be placed on the incisal/occlusal aspect of those teeth where the creation of interocclusal space is necessary. No mucosal-bone component should be involved * Thickness of the material placed should directly correspond to the required amount of inter-occlusal space, which will determine the increased in OVD as measured at specific site in the mouth. * An occlusal bite platform should be constructed ideally to ensure the occlusal forces are directed along the long axis of teeth. * Stable inter-occlusal contacts should be achieved. * Movement of the discluded teeth should not be impeded by the appliance.{{Cite journal|last=Poyser|first=N. J.|last2=Porter|first2=R. W. J.|last3=Briggs|first3=P. F. A.|last4=Chana|first4=H. S.|last5=Kelleher|first5=M. G. D.|date=2005-06-11|title=The Dahl Concept: past, present and future|url=http://www.nature.com/bdj/journal/v198/n11/full/4812371a.html?foxtrotcallback=true|journal=British Dental Journal|language=en|volume=198|issue=11|pages=669–676|doi=10.1038/sj.bdj.4812371|issn=0007-0610}} == Advantages == The advantages of this approach are: * minimal removal of tooth substance is required to create the interocclusal space * lost OVD can be restored * minimisation of facial aging by restoring facial height * safety * relative simplicity * relatively reversible * relatively cost effective approach == Success of Dahl concept == Planned occlusal changes can be tested using a removable appliance prior to permanent treatment. Dental composite based approaches to [[tooth surface loss]] allow for easy adjustment or removal if required. One study published in the British Dental Journal, 2011 found that patient satisfaction was high when composite restorations were used in the Dahl approach and that the median survival time was between 4.75 and 5.8 years.{{Cite journal|last=Gulamali|first=A. B.|last2=Hemmings|first2=K. W.|last3=Tredwin|first3=C. J.|last4=Petrie|first4=A.|date=2011-08-27|title=Survival analysis of composite Dahl restorations provided to manage localised anterior tooth wear (ten year follow-up)|url=http://www.nature.com/bdj/journal/v211/n4/full/sj.bdj.2011.683.html?foxtrotcallback=true|journal=British Dental Journal|language=en|volume=211|issue=4|pages=E9–E9|doi=10.1038/sj.bdj.2011.683|issn=0007-0610}} == See also == * [[Tooth wear]] ==References== # # {{Prosthodontology}} [[Category:Prosthodontology]] [[Category:Dentistry]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox hospital | Name = Donka Hospital | Org/Group = | Image = | image alt = | Caption = | map_type = Guinea Conakry | map_caption = The hospital's location in Conakry | Logo = | Logo Size = | Location = [[Conakry]] | Region = | State = | Country = Guinea | Coordinates = {{coord|9.537593|-13.682726|display=inline,title}} | HealthCare = | Funding = | Type = University Teaching Hospital | Beds = | Founded = | Closed = | Website = }} The '''Donka Hospital''' is a publicly owned hospital in [[Conakry]], [[Guinea]]. It has inadequate facilities to handle demand, and many Guineans cannot afford its services. More than once in recent years the hospital has had to deal with a major influx of patients wounded in civil disturbances.
==Facilities== Donka is a University Teaching Hospital, one of two in Conakry, the other being [[Ignace Deen Hospital]].<ref name=CBM/> It is located to the northeast of the [[Conakry Grand Mosque]] and across the main road from the infamous [[Camp Boiro]].<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AHX6dt6qicsC&pg=PA70 |page=70 |title=République de Guinée, Guinée-Bissau |author1=Dominique Auzias |author2=Jean-Paul Labourdette |author3=Alexandra Gazel |publisher=Petit Futé |year=2007 |ISBN=2-7469-1603-7}}</ref> It is the largest public hospital in the country, built in 1959 just before independence.<ref name=Inarus/> The [[Soviet Union]] assisted in its construction.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n9VDDVVqCTYC&pg=PA273 |page=273 |title=Le pouvoir politique en Guinée sous Sékou Touré |author=Mohamed Saliou Camara |publisher=Editions L'Harmattan |year=2007 |ISBN=2-296-03299-0}}</ref>
Sewage is treated by autonomous wastewater treatment plants funded by the World Bank.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/WDSP/IB/2006/07/26/000090341_20060726092636/Rendered/PDF/36083.pdf |title=IMPLEMENTATION COMPLETION REPORT ... REPUBLIC OF GUINEA ... WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION PROJECT |date=June 27, 2006 |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> The hospital receives priority supply of electricity, but blackouts were frequent in 2006 when oil prices soared. The hospital did not have enough money to pay for fuel for the main back-up power generator.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://royaldutchshellplc.com/2006/11/18/the-wall-street-journal-as-fuel-prices-soara-country-unravels/ |work=Wall Street Journal |title=As Fuel Prices Soar,A Country Unravels |date=Nov 18, 2006 |author=CHIP CUMMINS |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
The Orthopedic Department was established in February 1982. At that time, the main problems it addressed were neglected poliomyelitis cases.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://journals.lww.com/corr/Citation/1971/03000/Tendon_Transfers_for_Poliomyelitis_of_the_Lower.25.aspx |journal=Current Orthopaedic Practice |date=March–April 1971 |volume=75 |pages=188–194 |author1=Mourad Mestikawy |author2=Francis G. Zeir |title=Tendon Transfers for Poliomyelitis of the Lower Limb in Guinean Children |accessdate=2011-03-18 |doi=10.1097/00003086-197103000-00025}}</ref> In 2004, the West Africa Health Organization (WAHO), working with the Guinea Government, began giving two-year courses in ophthalmology for General Practice Doctors, with intensive theoretical and practical training. Facilities were insufficient. [[Christian Blind Mission|CBM]], [[Sightsavers]] and WAHO arranged to build a new facility in the teaching hospital compound, which was opened on 9 April 2010.<ref name=CBM/>
==Treatment== [[File:Pediatric doctors at Donka hospital reviewing mealses cases.jpg|thumb|300px|Pediatric doctors at Donka Hospital reviewing measles cases during an epidemic in 2009.]]
A 1989 study found that maternal mortality at the hospital was 12.47 per 1,000, an extremely high figure. Causes include lack of primary health care or peripheral obstetrical services, poor training of nurses and midwives and lack of general health education among the public.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=J Gynecol Obstet Biol Reprod (Paris) |year=1989 |volume=18 | issue = 7 |page=849-5 |pmid=2614023 |title=Maternal mortality at the University Hospital Center of Donka (Conakry, Guinea)]. |author1=Keita N |author2=Hizazy Y |author3=Diallo MS. }}</ref> In March 2011, the general wardroom for pre-mature babies in the Maternity Center had four incubators, but only one was working. It held five babies. The center is not equipped to handle the demand. About 80% of premature babies die within a few days.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theguineangazette.wordpress.com/2011/03/10/the-faith-of-pre-mature-babies-at-donka-hospital-conakry/ |title=The faith of pre-mature babies at Donka Hospital – Conakry |date=March 10, 2011 |author=C. M. Jalloh |accessdate=2011-03-18 |work=The Guinean Gazette}}</ref>
The Donka Hospital Institute of Nutrition and Child Health is the only children's hospital in Conakry. Between January and the end of September 2006, 623 malnourished children were admitted, a significant increase over previous years. The "dark, airless wards" were overcrowded, with some children sleeping two to a bed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=61675 |title=GUINEA: Malnutrition cases double in Conakry children’s hospital |date=28 November 2006 |publisher=[[IRIN]] |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
The hospital's dialysis department has five dialysis machines and can only treat 21 patients. There are private dialysis centers, but most patients cannot pay the $100 cost of the treatment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ihh.org.tr/siyah-tenli-diyarin-inci-yurekli-insanlari/en/ |title=Good-hearted people of the poor land |work=The Qurban |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> The Donka hospital provides training for mass marketing, communication and marketing aspects of prevention of HIV/AIDS, funded by the [[World Bank]] and other sources.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://irrico.bbconsult.co.uk/Factsheets//Microsoft%20Word%20-%20IRRICO_CS_GUINEA_Lay-out_revised%20by_MRF_BRUSSELS_EN.pdf |title=Information on Return and Reintegration in the Countries of Origin – IRRICO - GUINEA |publisher=IOM - International Organization for Migration |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
==Patient charges== The hospital has built up debt over the years, and cannot persuade the government or aid agencies to help with repayments. It therefore enforces a rigorous pay-as-you-go policy, which puts treatment and drugs out of reach of many poor people.<ref name=Inarus/> New patients must first be tested for life-threatening illnesses such as tuberculosis, AIDS, cholera, malaria and cancer.<ref name="Mariama Berey - A Case Study">{{cite web |url = http://www.woontanaraaid.org/whoweare.html |title = Mariama Berey - A Case Study |publisher = Woontanara Aid |accessdate = 2011-03-18 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120321141631/http://www.woontanaraaid.org/whoweare.html |archivedate = 2012-03-21 |df = }}</ref> The cost of a measles vaccine is as low as US$1.<ref name=IFRC2003114/>
Since many Guineans do not have enough money to pay for the blood test, they cannot get medical attention at the hospital.<ref name="Mariama Berey - A Case Study"/> The director of the hospital, Dr Taibou Barry, acknowledged the problem in 2003, saying: "The families are poor and when they come to the hospital, they have to pay for everything, and that’s probably all the money they have, so they must choose to eat or to come to the hospital".<ref name=IFRC2003114/>
A 2008 report from [[IRIN]] described the case of Aboubacar Traoré, who took his two-year-old daughter to the hospital for emergency medical treatment. Although the fee for consultation was $5, as shown on a sign on the wall, the doctor demanded more. Another doctor at the hospital said she was not surprised. She said "I have seen colleagues here persuade patients that only they can treat them, and once the patient has gained trust in that doctor, he or she bribes the patient".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=78535 |title=GUINEA: "We’ll treat you, if you pay the bribe," doctors say |date= 3 June 2008 |work=[[IRIN]] |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
== Civil unrest == At the start of 2007, strikes and protests were called due to rising commodity prices and falling living standards, coupled with pervasive corruption and political unrest. In the ensuing violence, about 180 people died and over 1,000 were injured.<ref name=MSF200712/> The [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC) provided six vehicles to take wounded people to Donka Hospital on 22 January 2007. 119 patients were admitted, most with bullet wounds. The ICRC supplied a surgical kit for treating up to 150 gunshot victims to the hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/news-release/guinea-news-240107.htm |title=Guinea: Coping with the tragic consequences of violence |date=2007-01-24 |publisher=[[ICRC]] |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> Donka hospital cared for at least 800 wounded people, assisted by [[Médecins Sans Frontières]].<ref name=MSF200712/> According to Djoulde Barry, director general of the hospital, 33 dead were registered there.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/RMOI-6XT2GY?OpenDocument&RSS20=18-P |title=Guinea: Strike spells more hardship |publisher=UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs - Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) |date=25 Jan 2007 |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
On 28 September 2009 a demonstration against the military junta at a city stadium was violently suppressed by security forces, with dozens of deaths and hundreds of injuries.<ref name=HRW/> Women reported that soldiers had raped them in public in the stadium. Medical records from Donka Hospital showed that at least 32 of the women protesters were raped.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/region/guinea/report-2010 |title=GUINEA - AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL REPORT 2010 |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> More than 220 first aid workers from the Red Cross Society of Guinea gave emergency medical assistance to more than 350 wounded people and took the most serious cases to the hospitals, mostly to the Donka National Hospital.<ref name=ICRC2009-12-21/> The injured packed the emergency room. Military from the Presidential Guard and Anti-Drug and Anti-Organized Crime Unit showed up around 3:00 pm that day. They fired their rifles into the air, destroyed medicines and yelled at the wounded to leave the hospital. They prevented anyone else from entering the building. The register of people treated was later lost.<ref name=HRW/>
Following the 28 September violence, the ICRC gave essential medical and surgical items to Conakry's hospitals, including kits to treat bullet wounds, masks, gloves and saline solution, and also provided body bags. The ICRC and the Red Cross Society of Guinea tried to reunite family members, particularly children, who had been separated in the violence.<ref name=ICRC2009-12-21/> The [[NGO]] [[Terre des hommes]] was providing meals to patients in the Hospital, with the Health Ministry and private donations assisting in the supply of food.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.africa.upenn.edu/afrfocus/afrfocus102309.html |title = Guinea: Aid Groups Mobilize to Help Wounded |date = 21 October 2009 |publisher = UN Integrated Regional Information Networks |accessdate = 2011-03-18 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100724234753/http://www.africa.upenn.edu//afrfocus/afrfocus102309.html |archivedate = 24 July 2010 |df = }}</ref> As follow-up to the violence, the ICRC helped Donka Hospital revise its emergency plan for handling a large influx of patients with bullet wounds.<ref name=ICRC2009-12-21/>
Further violence occurred before the October 2010 Presidential run-off elections. Supporters of the candidate [[Cellou Dalein Diallo]] of the [[Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea]] threw stones at police, who responded with gunfire. Two people were killed and at least 29 people were injured, treated in private clinics or Donka Hospital. The victims included "13 adolescents and three young girls".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iOAHOAQF1jgNXkbm1-Xp0JekYGgg?docId=CNG.ecf3b9ba4f1b34e86a551c3a8aefc644.8c1 |title=Two dead after Guinea police open fire on demonstrators |author=Mouctar Bah |publisher=AFP |date=Oct 19, 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> Violence continued after the elections, which were disputed. On 16 November 2010, Donka hospital reported treating 30 gunshot wounds, mostly direct shots rather than from stray bullets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/Violence-in-Guinea-after-Conde-elected-20101116 |title=More violence rocks Guinea |date=2010-11-16 |work=News 24 |author=Laurence Boutreux |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
==Western attention==
The bleak conditions in the hospital were the subject of a 1996 documentary ''Donka, radioscopie d'un hôpital africain'' by the Belgian director [[Thierry Michel]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://ks29982.kimsufi.com/passerelle/pres-equipe.php?m=4 |publisher = Les Films de la Passerelle SPRL |title = THIERRY MICHEL |accessdate = 2012-04-05 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120717164022/http://ks29982.kimsufi.com/passerelle/pres-equipe.php?m=4 |archivedate = 2012-07-17 |df = }}</ref> On 27 January 2009, a group of Marines from the U.S. Embassy delivered toys to each of the children at the Pediatric Hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conakry.usembassy.gov/pr_01272009.html |title=U.S. Marines Bring Toys to Hospitalized Children in Conakry |publisher=Embassy of the United States, Conakry |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> The actress [[Mia Farrow]], who serves as a [[UNICEF]] Goodwill Ambassador, visited the hospital in May 2010. She saw three newborn infants in one incubator in the maternity ward. She met mothers of severely malnourished children, and saw children fighting measles and other preventable childhood killer diseases. She said "It is wrenching to watch a child dying of a disease that is completely preventable. This is a result of Guinea's failing health system".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/media_53600.html |title=UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Mia Farrow completes visit to Guinea |date=10 May 2010 |publisher=UNICEF |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Health in Guinea]]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=CBM>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbm.org/article/Search-262088.php?q=donka&doSearch.x=0&doSearch.y=0 |title=DIPLOME D'ETUDE SUPERIEURE SPECIALISEE D'OPHTAMOLOGIE (DESSO) BASED AT CHU DONKA IN CONAKRY (GUINEA) |publisher=CBM |date=April 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> <ref name=HRW>{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/87186/section/14 |title=Boody Monday:VII. Military Takeover of Donka Hospital |date=17 December 2009 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> <ref name=ICRC2009-12-21>{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/update/guinea-update-181209.htm |title=Guinea: ICRC expands emergency-response capacities in unstable situation |date=2009-12-21 |publisher=ICRC |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> <ref name=IFRC2003114>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifrc.org/en/news-and-media/news-stories/africa/guinea/children-in-guinea-protected-against-measles/ |title=Children in Guinea protected against measles |date=2003-11-14 |author=Bonnie Gillespie |publisher=International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> <ref name=Inarus>{{cite web |url=http://icarusfilms.com/new97/donka___x.html |title=Donka: X-Ray of an African Hospital |publisher=Icarus Films |date=October 11, 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-18}}</ref> <ref name=MSF200712>{{cite web |url = http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/country.cfm?id=2321 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091214162410/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/country.cfm?id=2321 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2009-12-14 |title = MSF in Guinea |date = December 2007 |publisher = [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] |accessdate = 2011-03-18 }}</ref> }}
