School of Medicine. University of Navarra] * [http://www.unav.es/departamento/preventiva/sun The SUN cohort study at the Department of Preventive Medicine and Public Health web page. School of Medicine. University of Navarra] * [http://www.predimed.es PREDIMED main web page] * [http://dadun.unav.edu/browse?type=author&order=ASC&rpp=20&authority=10676 Dadun (Depósito Académico Digital Universidad de Navarra)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martinez, Miguel Angel}} [[Category:Nutritionists]] [[Category:Spanish public health doctors]] [[Category:21st-century Spanish physicians]] [[Category:20th-century Spanish physicians]] [[Category:University of Navarra faculty]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in the United Kingdom]]; added [[Category:Health care industry trade groups based in the United Kingdom]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''National Association of Primary Care''' is a membership association for clinicians and managers in the [[National Health Service]].
Dr Nav Chana is the chair of the association. It has offices in London.
Until 1998 it was called the National Association of Commissioning GPs and many of its members were involved with [[GP Fundholding]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Doctors' lobby group changes name to broaden primary care base|url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/home/leaders-signal-merger-of-primary-care-lobby-groups/32298.article|accessdate=25 January 2017|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=22 January 1998}}</ref>
It is involved in the development of plans associated with the [[Five Year Forward View]] for bringing GP practices together across populations of up to 50,000 patients in what it calls the 'primary care home'. This is similar to the multispeciality community provider model, but on a smaller scale.<ref>{{cite news|title='Huge appetite' for primary care at scale, says NHS England chief|url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/sectors/primary-care/huge-appetite-for-primary-care-at-scale-says-nhs-england-chief/7014020.article|accessdate=25 January 2017|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=7 December 2016}}</ref> This has been implemented in 15 pilot sites during 2016, covering around 500,000 patients.<ref>{{cite news|title=Primary care model for 50,000-patient groups to be extended across England|url=http://www.gponline.com/primary-care-model-50000-patient-groups-extended-across-england/article/1402112|accessdate=25 January 2017|publisher=GP Online|date=13 July 2016}}</ref> Occupational therapists, mental health therapists, clinical pharmacists and other clinical professionals are given a more prominent role in these organisations.<ref>{{cite news|title=How occupational therapists help keep older people out of hospital|url=https://www.theguardian.com/social-care-network/2016/jun/30/occupational-therapists-primary-care-keeping-older-people-out-of-hospital|accessdate=25 January 2017|publisher=Guardian|date=30 June 2016}}</ref> The [[Nuffield Trust]] produced a preliminary report on it in August 2017, which was quite positive, but found would need time, money and strong working relationships across the NHS and social care to be effective.<ref>{{cite news|title=New primary care model needs resources, say experts|url=https://www.onmedica.com/NewsArticle.aspx?id=e9635f31-4faf-4cd1-9c3d-bbcba720aff6|accessdate=8 October 2017|publisher=OnMedica|date=24 August 2017}}</ref>
[[Simon Stevens (NHS England)|Simon Stevens]] addressed a meeting of the association in October 2016 to explain plans for capital investment in 300 GP practices using the £900 million Estates and Technology Transformation Fund between 2016 and 2021.<ref>{{cite news|title=NHS England sets out funding for GP infrastructure, indemnity and mental health|url=http://www.gponline.com/nhs-england-sets-funding-gp-infrastructure-indemnity-mental-health/article/1412780|accessdate=25 January 2017|publisher=GP Online|date=19 October 2016}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Primary care]] [[Category:Health care industry trade groups based in the United Kingdom]]

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
See also [[Zuni ethnobotany]], and [[Native American ethnobotany]].
This is a list of plants utilized in [[Navajo people|Navajo]] culture. {{expand list|date=May 2013}} {{Compact ToC|side=yes|custom1=References|custom2=Bibliography|extlinks=yes}}
==A== * ''[[Abronia fragrans]]'' (snowball-sand verbena), used medicinally for boils<ref>Hocking, George M. 1956 Some Plant Materials Used Medicinally and Otherwise by the Navaho Indians in the Chaco Canyon, New Mexico. El Palacio 56:146–165 (p. 158)</ref> and taken internally when a spider was swallowed.<ref>Elmore, Francis H. 1944 Ethnobotany of the Navajo. Sante Fe, NM. School of American Research (p. 46)</ref> The [[Kayenta]] Navajo use it as a cathartic, for insect bites, as a sudorific, as an emetic, for stomach cramps, and as a general panacea.<ref>Wyman, Leland C. and Stuart K. Harris 1951 The Ethnobotany of the Kayenta Navaho. Albuquerque. The University of New Mexico Press (p. 21)</ref> The [[Ramah Navajo Indian Reservation|Ramah]] Navajo use it as a lotion for sores or sore mouth and to bathe perspiring feet.<ref>Vestal, Paul A. 1952 The Ethnobotany of the Ramah Navaho. Papers of the Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology 40(4):1–94 (p. 26)</ref> * ''[[Acer glabrum|Acer glabrum var. glabrum]]'' (Rocky Mountain maple), an infusion of which is used by the [[Ramah Navajo Indian Reservation|Ramah]] Navajo for swellings, and also as a "life medicine", or [[panacea]].<ref>Vestal, p. 36)</ref> * ''[[Acer negundo]]'' (box elder), the wood of which is used to make tubes for bellows.<ref>Elmore p. 62</ref> * ''[[Achillea millefolium]]'' (western yarrow), occidentalis variety used as a wash for cuts and saddle sores, and used as a "life medicine" for impaired vitality. Also used as a tonic.<ref>Elmore, p.79</ref> The [[Kayenta]] Navajo use it for headaches caused by weak or sore eyes, and as a lotion around eyes that are sore from wearing ceremonial masks. They also use it as a [[febrifuge]].<ref>Wyman and Harris p. 44</ref> [[Ramah Navajo Indian Reservation|Ramah]] Navajo use it as a ceremonial emetic.<ref>Vestal, p.47</ref> *''[[Acourtia wrightii]]'' (brownfoot), used by the Kayenta Navajo for difficult labor and as a postpartum medicine.<ref>Wyman and Harris, p.49</ref> * ''[[Adiantum capillus-veneris]]'' (southern maidenhair fern), an infusion of which is used by the Kayenta Navajo as a lotion for bumblebee and centipede stings. They also use an infusion to treat insanity, and smoke the plant for the same purpose.<ref>Wyman and Harris, p.14</ref> *''[[Agastache pallidiflora]]'' (New Mexico giant hyssop), used by the Ramah as a ceremonial chant lotion, for bad coughs, and the dried, pulverized root used as dusting powder for sores or cankers. The Ramah also use it a [[fumigant]] for "deer infection", as a [[febrifuge]], and to protect from witches.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Agastache+pallidiflora</ref> * ''[[Agave]]'', the baked fibers of which are squeezed, and the liquid drunk. The heads are baked or boiled, pounded into flat sheets, sun dried and stored for future use. The baked, dried heads are also boiled and made into an edible paste, eaten whole, or made into soup. The leaves are also boiled and eaten. The young, tender flowering stalks are and shoots are roasted and eaten as well. The fibers are used to make rope, the leaves are used to line baking pits, and the sharp pointed leaf tips are used to make basketry awls.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Agave</ref> * ''[[Agave utahensis]]'' (Utah agave), the fibers of which are used to make blankets.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Agave+utahensis</ref> * ''[[Ageratina herbacea]]'' (fragrant snakeroot), cold infusion taken and used as a lotion for headache and fever by the Ramah Navajo.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Ageratina+herbacea</ref> * ''[[Agoseris aurantiaca]]'' (orange agoseris), taken by the Ramah as a ceremonial emetic. A cold infusion is taken and used as lotion for arrow or bullet wounds, for "deer infection", and for protection against witches. Wet leaves rubbed on swollen arms, wrists or ankles. The root is used a [[panacea|life medicine]].<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Agoseris +aurantiaca</ref> * ''[[Allionia incarnata]]'', a cold infusion of which is used by the Ramah as a lotion for swellings.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Allionia+incarnata</ref> * ''[[Androsace septentrionalis]]'', (pygmyflower rockjasmine), used by the Kayenta for the bewitchment and pain from witches' arrows.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Androsace+septentrionalis</ref> * ''[[Antennaria]]'', used in ceremonies for protection from witchcraft.<ref name="Vestal47">Vestal, Paul A. 1952 The Ethnobotany of the Ramah Navaho. Papers of the Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology 40(4):1–94 (p. 47)</ref> * ''[[Artemisia tridentata]]'', vaporized to treat headaches.<ref name="Tilford">''Edible and Medicinal Plants of the West'', Gregory L. Tilford, {{ISBN|0-87842-359-1}} {{page needed|date=July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Kay, Margarita|title=Healing with Plants|publisher=University of Arizona Press|year=1996|isbn=9780186516465|pages=106–107|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YWygHKquonoC&pg=PA106}}</ref> It is also used for colds, as a febrifuge, and in religious and medicinal ceremonies. A decoction is used for stomachaches, and an infusion is taken by women to help with childbirth. The plant is also taken before long hikes to rid the body of lingering, undesirable things. The Kayenta Navajo use it as a [[laxative]], and an infusion of the plant is taken and used as a lotion for snakebites. The Ramah Navajo use a decoction of the leaves for postpartum pain, and for "big cough". They also apply a poultice of the wet leaves to swellings, use it [[diaphoretic]] in sweatbaths, and apply a cold infusion of the leaves as a lotion for cuts on sheep.<ref>http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Artemisia +tridentata</ref>
==B== * ''[[Baccharis salicifolia]]'' (mulefat), used by the [[Kayenta]] in a compound infusion of plants used as a lotion for chills from immersion.<ref>Wyman and Harris, p. 45</ref>
==C== * ''[[Ceanothus fendleri]]'', combined with [[Frasera]] to make a medicine applied internally or externally, for "alarm and nervousness".<ref name=Elmore>{{cite book | author=Elmore, Francis H. | title=Trees and Shrubs of the Southwest Uplands | publisher=Western National Parks Association | year=1976 | pages = 121 | isbn = 0-911408-41-X}}</ref> * ''[[Commelina dianthifolia]]'', given a cold simple or compound [[infusion]] by the [[Ramah Navajo]] to livestock as an [[aphrodisiac]].<ref>Vestal, Paul A. 1952 The Ethnobotany of the Ramah Navaho. Papers of the Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology 40(4):1–94 (p. 19)</ref> * ''[[Cordylanthus ramosus]]'', an infusion of which is used as an [[emetic]]. This infusion is also used to treat syphilis, used by menstruating women to stop menses, and by men to stop nosebleeds. The plant is also used to prevent broken ribs.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Cordylanthus+ramosus Ethnobotany]</ref>
==D== * ''[[Dalea candida|Dalea candida, candida variety]]'' (white prairieflower), used by the Ramah for stomachache, for "life medicine", especially for fever, and a compound decoction used to treat "snake infection" in sheep.<ref>Vestal, Paul A. 1952 The Ethnobotany of the Ramah Navaho. Papers of the Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology 40(4):1–94 (p. 33)</ref>
*''[[Draba reptans]]'' – The [[Ramah Navajo]] apply a [[poultice]] of the crushed leaves of the plant to sores.<ref>Vestal, Paul A., 1952, The Ethnobotany of the Ramah Navaho, Papers of the Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology 40(4):1–94, page 28</ref>
==E== * ''[[Euphorbia revoluta]]'', used as a lotion by the [[Kayenta]] for chafing and sores.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Chamaesyce+revoluta Ethnobotany]</ref>
==F== * ''[[Fendlera rupicola]]'', an infusion of the inner bark is used as a remedy when were swallowed.<ref name=EF>Elmore, Francis H. 1944 Ethnobotany of the Navajo. Sante Fe, NM. School of American Research (p. 51)</ref> Also used to kill head lice.<ref name="EF"/> and as a cathartic.<ref name=LH>Wyman, Leland C. and Stuart K. Harris 1951 The Ethnobotany of the Kayenta Navaho. Albuquerque. The University of New Mexico Press (p. 25)</ref> This plant is also used in plumeway, nightway, male shootingway and windway ceremonies,<ref name="LH"/> and the wood is used to make arrow shafts.<ref name=EF/><ref name="autogenerated221"/> * ''[[Frasera]]'', combined with ''[[Ceanothus fendleri]]'' to make a medicine applied internally or externally, for "alarm and nervousness".<ref name="Elmore"/>
==G== * ''[[Gutierrezia microcephala]]'', a poultice of which is applied to the back and legs of horses.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hocking|first=George M.|title=Some Plant Materials Used Medicinally and Otherwise by the Navaho Indians in the Chaco Canyon, New Mexico|journal=El Palacio|year=1956|volume=63|url=http://www.chacoarchive.org/docs/000846complete.pdf|accessdate=December 29, 2012|page=151}}</ref>
==I== * ''[[Iris missouriensis]]''; a decoction of which is used as an emetic.<ref>Peter Goldblatt. 1980. [https://www.jstor.org/pss/2418516 Uneven Diploid Chromosome Numbers and Complex Heterozygosity in ''Homeria'' (Iridaceae)]. Systematic Botany, Vol. 5, No. 4, pp. 337–340</ref>
==J== *''[[Juniperus communis]]'', used as an herbal remedy for diabetes among the Navajo.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Herbal Therapies and Diabetes Among Navajo Indians | year = 2005 | journal = [[Diabetes Care]] | pages = 1534–1535 | volume = 28 | issue = 6 | doi = 10.2337/diacare.28.6.1534-a | last1 = McCabe | first1 = Melvina | last2 = Gohdes | first2 = Dorothy | last3 = Morgan | first3 = Frank | last4 = Eakin | first4 = Joanne | last5 = Sanders | first5 = Margaret | last6 = Schmitt | first6 = Cheryl }}</ref>
==L== * ''[[Lithospermum ruderale]]'', used as a contraceptive.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Lithospermum+ruderale Ethnobotany]</ref> Studies on [[House Mouse|mice]] showed that the plant reduced their [[fertility]].<ref>[http://www.mobot.org/MOBOT/On-LineExhibit/Nevada/nevada10.html MoBot Online Exhibit]</ref> * ''[[Lycium pallidum]]'', used for toothache and for [[chicken pox]].<ref name=mich>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Lycium+pallidum ''Lycium pallidum''.] University of Michigan Ethnobotany.</ref>
==P== * ''[[Packera multilobata]]'', used medicinally.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Packera+multilobata Ethnobotany]</ref> * ''[[Pericome caudata]]'', used for a variety of ceremonial and medicinal uses.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Pericome+caudata Ethnobotany]</ref> * ''[[Picea pungens]]'', used medicinally and ceremonially.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Picea+pungens U. Michigan-Dearborn: Ethnobotany] . accessed 1.12.2012</ref> * ''[[Pinus flexilis]]'' is used to create bowd and arrows for ceremonial use.<ref>Elmore, Francis H. 1944 Ethnobotany of the Navajo. Sante Fe, NM. School of American Research (p. 23)</ref> * ''[[Prunus americana]]'', used to make a red dye.<ref>Elmore, Francis H. (1944). ''Ethnobotany of the Navajo.'' Monograph Series: 1(7). Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico. 136 p.</ref> * ''[[Psilostrophe tagetina]]'', used by [[Ramah Navajo Indian Reservation|Ramah]] Navajo to create a strong infusion as cathartic, also used to treat stomachache, as an eyewash, as a lotion for itching, or in cold infusion gargled or in poultice of leaves applied for sore throat.<ref>{{cite web|title=Psilostrophe tagetina|url=http://herb.umd.umich.edu/|work=University of Michigan Dearborn|accessdate=27 April 2011}}</ref>
==T== * ''[[Thelesperma megapotamicum]]'' used to make a yellow dye, and as medicinal tisane.<ref name="umich1">[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Thelesperma+megapotamicum Ethnobotany]</ref> and in their plumeway, nightway, male shootingway and windway ceremonies,<ref name="LH"/> and to make arrow shafts.<ref name=EF/><ref name="autogenerated221">Weber, Steven A. and P. David Seaman 1985 Havasupai Habitat: A. F. Whiting's Ethnography of a Traditional Indian Culture. Tucson. The University of Arizona Press (p. 221)</ref> It is also used to make notched and smooth sticks which are rubbed together in their mountain chant ceremony, and to make weaving forks, planting sticks, and knitting needles.<ref name=EF/><ref name="autogenerated221"/> They also boil the plant with juniper berries, pinon buds, and cornmeal for ceremonial consumption.<ref name="LH"/>
==V== *''[[Viola nephrophylla]]'', used by the [[Ramah Navajo]] as a ceremonial [[emetic]].<ref>Vestal, Paul A., 1952, The Ethnobotany of the Ramah Navaho, Papers of the Peabody Museum of American Archaeology and Ethnology 40(4):1–94, page 36</ref>
==Z== * ''[[Zinnia grandiflora]]'', used for medicinal purposes.<ref>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Zinnia+grandiflora Ethnobotany]</ref>
==See also== * [[Native American ethnobotany]] * [[Navajo medicine]] * [[Zuni ethnobotany]]
==References== {{reflist|26em}}
[[Category:Navajo culture|Ethnobotany]] [[Category:Plants used in traditional Native American medicine|*]] [[Category:Flora of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Lists of flora of the United States]] [[Category:Medical lists]] [[Category:Plants used in Native American cuisine|*]]

[[File:Circumpolar AZ81.jpg|thumb|300px| Night owls may make natural amateur astronomers.]]
A '''night owl''', '''evening person''' or simply '''owl''', is a person who tends to stay up until late at night. In several countries, especially in [[Scandinavia]], early birds are called ''A-people'' and night owls are called ''B-people''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2370239,00.html|title=Late Sleepers in Denmark Rally for Societal Change|last=James|first=Kyle|date=1 March 2007|accessdate=2009-11-01|publisher=Deutsche Welle}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/6749791.stm|title=Late risers unite in Denmark|last=Morris|first=Chris|date=14 June 2007|accessdate=2009-11-01|publisher=BBC News Channel}}</ref> Night owls who are involuntarily unable to fall asleep for several hours after a normal time may have [[Delayed sleep phase disorder|delayed sleep phase syndrome]].
The opposite of a night owl is an [[lark (person)|early bird]] – a [[Lark (person)|lark]] as opposed to an owl – which is someone who tends to begin sleeping at a time that is considered early and also wakes early. Researchers traditionally use the terms ''morningness'' and ''eveningness''<ref>{{cite journal |author=Horne JA, Östberg O |title=A self-assessment questionnaire to determine morningness-eveningness in human circadian rhythms |journal=Int J Chronobiol |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=97–110 |year=1976 |pmid=1027738}}</ref> for the two [[chronotype]]s or [[diurnality]] and [[nocturnality]] in animal behavior.
==Etymology==
[[File:Asio otus uszatka1.JPG|thumb|Owls, like this one in Poland, are often nocturnal.]]
The term is derived from the primarily nocturnal habits of the [[owl]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/night--owl?s=t|title=Night owl|last=|first=|date=|website=www.dictionary.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> Most owls sleep during the day and hunt for food at night.
==Characteristics==
Usually, people who are night owls stay awake past midnight, and extreme night owls may stay awake until just before or even after dawn.<ref>Stefan Klein, ''Time'' (2008) p. 20</ref> Night owls tend to feel most energetic just before they go to sleep at night.
Some night owls have a preference or habit for staying up late, or stay up to work the [[shift work|night shift]]. Night owls who work the day shift often have difficulties adapting to standard daytime working hours.
Night owls have often been blamed for unpunctuality or attitude problems.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/85817911|title=Insomniac|last=Greene|first=Gayle|date=|publisher=University of California Press|year=2008|isbn=9780520259966|location=Berkeley|pages=345|oclc=85817911}}</ref> Employers, however, have begun to learn to increase productivity by respecting body clocks through flexible working hours,<ref>Klein, p. 33</ref> while the Danish "B-Society" of night owls<ref name=":2" /> and the American [[Start School Later movement]] lobby actively for more school and workplace flexibility for the post-agricultural world.<ref name=":2" />
Some research has found that night owls are more intelligent and creative and more likely to get high-paying jobs than larks. A study among 1000 adolescents by the University of Madrid found that owls are better than early birds in intuitive intelligence, [[creative thinking]] and [[Inductive reasoning aptitude|inductive reasoning]]. However, they lag behind larks in academic performance,<ref>"[https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/if-you-want-to-get-ahead-be-a-night-owl-8547115.html IF YOU WANT TO GET AHEAD, BE A NIGHT OWL]" by Roger Dobson; ''THE INDEPENDENT'' March 24, 2013</ref> and they tend to have unhealthier eating habits.<ref>Walker, R. J., Christopher, A. N., Wieth, M. B., & Buchanan, J. (2015). Personality, time-of-day preference, and eating behavior: The mediational role of morning-eveningness. Personality and Individual Differences, 77, 13–17.</ref>
Some night owls with great difficulty adopting normal [[sleep]]ing and waking times may have [[Delayed sleep phase disorder|delayed sleep-phase disorder]]. Morning [[light therapy]] may be helpful in shifting sleep rhythms for the night owl.<ref>Laura H. Smith/Charles H. Elliott, ''Seasonal Affective Disorder for Dummies'' (2007) p. 73</ref>
== Factors == The tendency to be a night owl exists on a [[spectrum]], with most people being typical, some people having a small or moderate tendency to be a night owl, and a few having an extreme tendency to be a night owl.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Roenneberg|first=Till|last2=Merrow|first2=Martha|date=23 May 2016|title=The Circadian Clock and Human Health|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960982216303335|journal=Current Biology|volume=26|issue=10|pages=R432–R443|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2016.04.011|via=}}</ref> An individual's own tendency can change over time and is influenced by multiple factors, including:
* a genetic predisposition, which can cause the tendency to run in families, * the person's age, with teenagers and young adults tending to be night owls more than young children or elderly people, and * the environment the person lives in, especially the patterns of light they are exposed to through seasonal changes as well as through lifestyle (such as spending the day indoors and using electric lights in the evening).<ref name=":0" />
The genetic make-up of the [[Circadian rhythm|circadian timing system]] underpins the difference between early and late chronotypes, or early birds and night owls.<ref>Philip Lee Williams, ''On the Morning'' (2006) p. 41</ref> While it has been suggested that circadian rhythms may change over time, including dramatic changes that turn a morning lark to a night owl or vice versa,<ref>Jeff Belanger/Kirsten Dalley, ''The Nightmare Encyclopedia'' (2005) p. 83</ref><ref>Walker, R. J., Kribs, Z. D., Christopher, A. N., Shewach, O. R., & Wieth, M. B. (2014). Age, the Big Five, and time-of-day preference: A mediational model. Personality and Individual Differences, 56, 170–174.</ref> evidence for familial patterns of early or late waking would seem to contradict this, and individual changes are likely on a smaller scale.<ref>Klein, p. 21</ref>
==Prevalence== A 2007 survey of over 55,000 people found that [[Chronotype|chronotypes]] tend to follow a [[normal distribution]], with extreme morning and evening types on the far ends.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roenneberg|first=Till|last2=Kuehnle|first2=Tim|last3=Juda|first3=Myriam|last4=Kantermann|first4=Thomas|last5=Allebrandt|first5=Karla|last6=Gordijn|first6=Marijke|last7=Merrow|first7=Martha|date=December 2007|title=Epidemiology of the human circadian clock|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1087079207000895|journal=Sleep Medicine Reviews|volume=11|issue=6|pages=429–438|doi=10.1016/j.smrv.2007.07.005|issn=1087-0792|via=}}</ref>
== Career options == Night owls tend to thrive in careers that do not require working in the early morning. People who want to work in the evening are often employed at restaurants, hotels, entertainment venues, retail stores, and some [[personal care]] businesses.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/careeroutlook/2015/article/night-owls-and-early-birds.htm|title=Career Outlook: Careers for night owls and early birds|last=Torpey|first=Elka|date=October 2015|website=U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-06}}</ref> Night owls who work the night shift may work in [[Emergency service|emergency services]], in transportation, or at round-the-clock facilities, such as hospitals and some manufacturing plants.<ref name=":1" />
Many businesses that operate in the evening or at night need employees at all levels, from entry-level employees to managers to skilled staff, whenever they are open. For example, most hospitals employ many types of workers around the clock:
* non-medical staff such as security guards, [[Technology Specialist|IT specialists]], cleaning and maintenance workers, cooks and food service staff, and admissions clerks; * medical staff such as nurses, [[Paramedic|paramedics]], radiology technicians, [[Pharmacist|pharmacists]], and [[phlebotomists]]; * managers for each of the main hospital wards or activities, including janitorial supervisors and [[Head nurse|head nurses]].
Industries that tend to be less favorable to night owls include farming, construction, and working for [[Public utility|public utilities]]. Many employees in these industries start working before 7:00 a.m.<ref name=":1" />
==Famous exemplars==
A list of famous night owls includes: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Charles Bukowski]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Authors' sleep patterns & productivity|url=http://shortlist.com/entertainment/books/authors-sleep-patterns-and-productivity|publisher=[[ShortList]]}}</ref> * [[Fidel Castro]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/feb/19/castro.battle|title=Castro: his last battle|date=2008-02-19|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> * [[Michael Chabon]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Winston Churchill]]<ref>{{cite web|title=11 Bizarre Sleeping Habits Of Highly Successful People|url=http://www.sfgate.com/technology/businessinsider/article/11-Bizarre-Sleeping-Habits-Of-Highly-Successful-5006320.php|publisher=[[SF Gate]]}}</ref> * [[Bob Dylan]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Gustave Flaubert]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Glenn Gould]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Samuel Johnson]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Carl Jung]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Authors' sleep patterns & productivity|url=http://shortlist.com/entertainment/books/authors-sleep-patterns-and-productivity|publisher=[[shortList]]}}</ref> * [[Franz Kafka]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Fran Lebowitz]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2010/11/fran_lebowitz_interview_transc.html|title=The Vulture Transcript: Fran Lebowitz on Sarah Palin, Keith Richards, Her Side Career As a Law & Order Judge, and Much More|publisher=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]}}</ref> * [[Marilyn Manson]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.spin.com/2007/05/cover-marilyn-manson/|title=On the Cover: Marilyn Manson|date=2007-05-17|work=Spin|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> * [[Mao Zedong]]<ref>{{cite book|title=The New Emperors|author=[[Harrison Salisbury]]|publisher=HarperCollins|year=1992|page=103}}</ref> * [[Frank Meyer (political philosopher)|Frank Meyer]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Buckley|first=William F.|authorlink=William F. Buckley|title=Miles Gone Bye: A Literary Autobiography|publisher=[[Regnery Publishing]]|isbn=978-0895260895}}</ref> * [[Barack Obama]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Buncombe|first1=Andrew|title=Barack Obama: The nocturnal habits of America's ‘night guy’ president revealed|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/barack-obama-nocturnal-habits-of-americas-night-guy-president-revealed-a7115561.html|accessdate=19 January 2018|work=The Independent|date=2 July 2016}}</ref> * [[Prince (musician)|Prince]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.etonline.com/news/187368_inside_prince_secret_midnight_movie_screenings_at_local_minnesota_theater/|title= EXCLUSIVE: Inside Prince's Secret Midnight Outings|publisher=[[Antoinette Bueno]]}}</ref> * [[Marcel Proust]]<ref name="slate">{{cite web|title=Daily Rituals: Marcel Proust, Franz Kafka, and other artists who did great work in the wee hours.|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/features/2013/daily_rituals/marcel_proust_franz_kafka_and_other_artists_who_did_their_best_work_at_night.html|publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]}}</ref> * [[George Sand]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[Joseph Stalin]]<ref>{{cite book|last=McCullough|first=David|authorlink=David McCullough|title=Truman|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|page=508|isbn= 978-0671456542}}</ref> * [[Hunter S. Thompson]]<ref>{{cite book|last=McKeen|first=William|authorlink=William McKeen|title=Outlaw Journalist: The Life and Times of Hunter S. Thompson|publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]]|quote=Sandy maintained the house, tiptoeing around until three o'clock in the afternoon, Hunter's usual waking hour.|page=104|isbn=978-0-393-06192-5}}</ref> * [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zWzAAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT188&lpg=PT188&dq=jrr+tolkien+I+go+to+bed+late+and+get+up+late&source=bl&ots=-RLPkqp5Z6&sig=DG9WkyW-a-2lr1u9ZOXeEsyWUI4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiCqYeB0uPZAhVDj1kKHU95CxEQ6AEIUDAF#v=onepage&q=jrr%20tolkien%20I%20go%20to%20bed%20late%20and%20get%20up%20late&f=false|title=J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography|last=Carpenter|first=Humphrey|date=2014-03-04|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=9780547524429|language=en}}</ref> * [[Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec]]<ref name="slate"/> * [[John Travolta]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1554542/Travolta-turns-night-owl-to-protect-privacy.html|title = Travolta turns night owl to protect privacy|last = Elsworth|first = Catherine|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 2016-03-07}}</ref> * [[Linus Torvalds]]<ref name="slate"/> }}
==Literary examples==
For [[Robert Louis Stevenson]], "there is a romance about all those who are abroad in the black hours."<ref>Quoted in Rubinstein p. 211</ref>
In [[Jayne Ann Krentz]]'s ''Truth or Dare'', "Arcadia and Harry were both creatures of the night. They managed to appear oddly stylish at one-thirty in the morning."<ref>Jayne Ann Krentz, ''Truth and Dare'' (Penguin 2004) p. 258</ref>
British author [[Hilary Rubinstein]] wrote: "Blessed are the owls, for they shall inherit the mystery and magic of the night."<ref>Hilary Rubinstein, ''The Complete Insomniac'' (London 1974) p. 19</ref>
In [[Pliny the Elder]]'s [[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]], he states ''Vita vigila est'', "to be alive is to be watchful", a military metaphor for keeping watch in the night.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OrJ0CgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&lpg=PP7&dq=to+be+alive+is+to+be+watchful+pliny&source=bl&ots=dV9Qo0vGA1&sig=-zCJKZtOdoQADWunf836JrjOndc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj8nKGm3cXaAhUQPN8KHX7rBHkQ6AEINjAB#v=onepage&q=to%20be%20alive%20is%20to%20be%20watchful%20pliny&f=false|title=Delphi Complete Works of Pliny the Elder (Illustrated)|last=Elder|first=Pliny the|date=2015-08-29|publisher=Delphi Classics|language=en}}</ref>
In The [[Little River Band]], hit "The Night Owls": "be strong, find the heart of a night owl falling/Stay up till dawn until the night is gone"<ref>The Little River Band All-Time Greatest Hits 1990 CEMA Special Markets</ref>
==See also==
* [[Chronobiology]] – the study of sleep cycles and other time-dependent biological systems * [[Circadian rhythm sleep disorder]] * [[Delayed sleep phase disorder]] – an extreme form of being a night owl * [[Insomnia]] – the inability to fall asleep or stay asleep * [[Lark (person)]] – a person who has difficulty staying awake in the evening, and wakes early * [[Morningness–eveningness questionnaire]] (MEQ) * [[Munich Chronotype Questionnaire|Munich ChronoType Questionnaire]] (MCTQ) * [[Zeitgeber]] – environmental factors, such as bright light, that reinforce sleep–wake cycles
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading==
* [[Louise Miller (writer)|Louise Miller]], ''Careers for Night Owls and Other Insomniacs'' (2002) * [[J. Dunlap]] et al., ''Chronobiology'' (2004)
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090718152336/http://www.nightworkers.com/discrimation.html Sleep Discrimination] * [https://neuroon.com/news/intelligence-and-creativity-night-owls-vs-early-bi/ Intelligence and Creativity in Night Owls vs. Early Birds] with several references to different studies * [http://news.health.ufl.edu/2017/26884/multimedia/health-in-a-heartbeat/sleep-deprivation-impacts-night-owls-and-early-risers-differently/ Sleep deprivation impacts night owls and early risers differently]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Night Owl (Person)}} [[Category:Sleep]] [[Category:Circadian rhythm]] [[Category:Night]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Smasongarrison|Smasongarrison]])
revision.text:
'''Nikolai Evgenievich Khokhlov''' ([[Cyrillic]]: Николай Евгеньевич Хохлов) (7 June 1922, [[Nizhny Novgorod]] - 17 September 2007 [[San Bernardino, California]]) was a [[KGB]] officer who defected to the [[United States]] in 1954. He testified about KGB activities. The KGB unsuccessfully tried to kill him with poison in 1957.
==Family background== Khokhlov's parents divorced when he was very young. He was not well-acquainted with his father, who later served as a [[commissar]] in the [[Red Army]]. During the [[Battle for Moscow]], the elder Khokhlov was transferred to a [[penal battalion]] because he had made unfavourable remarks about [[Joseph Stalin]]. Khokhlov's father died in the battalion.
His stepfather, a lawyer, volunteered to defend [[Moscow]] in 1941 and died in action almost immediately. As Khokhlov later put it, "The army needed cannon fodder".<ref>Andrew Nagorski: The Greatest Battle, 2007, pp. 198-199 </ref>
==NKVD career== In October 1941, Khokhlov, then 19 years old, was a member of an [[NKVD]] quartet who were trained to commit a spectacular attack against [[Nazi]] officers during their victory celebration in the occupied [[Moscow]]. The mastermind behind the plan was [[Mikhail Maklyarskiy]], a senior NKVD official. The four young agents would have played a vaudeville group on the celebration. Khokhlov was chosen for his role on his whistling abilities. During the training, he had his first great romance with fellow agent, singer [[Tasya Ignatova]]. After the German retreat from the outskirts of Moscow, the deadly show was cancelled.<ref>Andrew Nagorski: The Greatest Battle, 2007, pp. 196-198</ref>
Nikolai Khokhlov was a member of a successful military unit that fought behind the enemy lines during [[World War II]]. He was disguised as a Nazi officer after parachuting into German-occupied [[Belarus]]. He played a part in the assassination of [[Wilhelm Kube]], the Nazi [[Gauleiter]] of [[Belarus]]. After the war, Khokhlov became the prototype for the main character in a 1947 Soviet film, [[Secret Agent (1947 film)|''Feat of a Scout'']] ("Подвиг разведчика").
==Assassination mission== In 1954, Khokhlov was sent by the [[KGB]] to supervise two other men whose task was to kill Georgiy Okolovich, a chairman of the [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]]. He decided not to follow the order and discussed the situation with his wife, Yana, who said, "If this man is killed, you will be a murderer. I cannot be the wife of a murderer."<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-2480635,00.html Times Online]</ref> Khokhlov went to Okolovich's flat in [[Frankfurt]] and told him: "Georgiy Sergeyevich, I have come to you from Moscow. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union has ordered your assassination. The murder is entrusted to my group... I can’t let this murder happen."<ref name="Andrew">*[[Christopher Andrew (historian)|Christopher Andrew]] and [[Vasili Mitrokhin]], ''The [[Mitrokhin Archive]]: The KGB in Europe and the West'', Gardners Books (2000), {{ISBN|0-14-028487-7}}</ref> In retaliation, his wife was arrested and sentenced to five years of [[Involuntary settlements in the Soviet Union|involuntary settlement]] in the Soviet Union. Khokhlov defected to the United States following his failure to carry out the assassination order.
==Poisoning by thallium== Khokhlov was treated for [[thallium]] poisoning in Frankfurt in 1957,<ref>[http://2004.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2004/46n/n46n-s10.shtml Meeting with past (Russian)]</ref> as a result of a failed assassination attempt by the [[Thirteenth Department]] of the [[KGB]].<ref name="Andrew"/> This case is often claimed to be the first [[radiological poisoning|radiological attack]] by the [[KGB]], especially when comparison with the [[poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko]]<ref name="dissident">[[Alexander Goldfarb (microbiologist)|Alex Goldfarb]] and Marina Litvinenko. ''[[Death of a dissident|Death of a Dissident: The Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko and the Return of the KGB]]'', The Free Press (2007) {{ISBN|1-4165-5165-4}}; Boris Volodarsky. ''[[The KGB's Poison Factory: From Lenin to Litvinenko]]'', Frontline Books (2009) {{ISBN|978-1-84832-542-5}},</ref> is drawn, although it remains unclear what isotope was used, if any.<ref name=hps>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hps.org/publicinformation/ate/q6833.html |title=Category: Radiation Basics |access-date=2008-04-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019100238/https://hps.org/publicinformation/ate/q6833.html |archive-date=2007-10-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Former KGB officer Stanislav Lekarev claimed, however, that Khokhlov was poisoned by radioactive polonium (not thallium), exactly as Litvinenko was.<ref>{{YouTube|zruZjhvJ0VQ|Who Killed Litvinenko? - Russia}}</ref> Litvinenko's poisoning was also initially mistaken for thallium.
==Life in the United States== {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2018}} After graduating with a PhD from [[Duke University]], Khokhlov taught undergraduate and graduate psychology classes at [[California State University, San Bernardino]] from 1968 to 1992. He retired as a professor emeritus in 1993. In 1992, Russian President [[Boris Yeltsin]] pardoned him. Khokhlov returned to Moscow for a short stay, for the first time since the 1950s. He later made an e-mail contact with, then eventually met, his son in Russia of whom he had not been previously aware. In the United States, Khokhlov married again. With his second wife Tanja, he had two daughters and a son, Misha, who died several years later due to a kidney failure.
In 2006, Khokhlov compared his poisoning half a century ago to the murder of Litvinenko. "The situation within Russia today is very perilous. There are no more laws, and no more order. Putin brought back many KGB, and there are too many KGB at the top, the old dinosaurs who cannot get rid of old habits", he added.
Nikolai Khokhlov died of a heart attack in San Bernardino, California, in September 2007. He was buried next to the grave of his son.
==See also== * [[Alexander Litvinenko poisoning]] * [[List of Eastern Bloc defectors]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Books== *Nikolai Evgenievich Khokhlov. ''In the name of conscience ''. Translated by Emily Kingsbery. New York : David McKay, 1959. [http://antisoviet.imwerden.de/hohlov_n_pravo.pdf In the name of conscience (Russian)] *Boris Volodarsky. ''Nikolai Khokhlov ("Whistler"), Self-Esteem with a Halo ''. Vienna-London : Borwall Verlag, 2005. [http://www.worldcat.org/title/nikolai-khokhlov-self-esteem-with-a-halo/oclc/180502046 (English)] *Boris Volodarsky. ''The KGB's Poison Factory: From Lenin to Litvinenko ''. London/Barnsley : Frontline Books, 2009, pp. 166-81; {{ISBN|978-1-84832542-5}}. [https://www.amazon.co.uk/d/Books/KGBs-Poison-Factory-Lenin-Litvinenko/1848325428/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1487797578&sr=1-1&keywords=the+kgb%27s+poison+factory (English)]
==External links== *[http://www.synodinresistance.org/Annals_en/E2d030khokhlov.pdf Obituary] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080308174016/http://www.hoover.org/publications/digest/8138382.html A brief history of Soviet torturers and assassins, some of whom had second thoughts]. By Katya Drozdova, [[Hoover Institute]] *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-2480635,00.html Newspaper Article: Times Online] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080227020358/http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/topstories/2007/07/21/i-led-kgb-hit-squad-89520-19489242/ I led KGB hit squad] by Ros Wynne Jones *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080409083337/http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/2007-34-32.cfm One more time on the Alexander Litvinenko case] by Vadim Birstein *[http://www.svoboda.org/programs/TD/2002/TD.102002.asp Interview] to [[Radio Free Europe]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Khokhlov, Nikolai}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet intelligence personnel who defected to the United States]] [[Category:Victims of radiological poisoning]] [[Category:KGB officers]] [[Category:Soviet Army officers]] [[Category:People sentenced to death in absentia by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Russian anti-communists]] [[Category:American anti-communists]] [[Category:Soviet assassins]]

{{Infobox organization | name = {{big|Nyumbani Orphanage }} | former name = | image = Nyumbanilogo.png | image_border = | size = | caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = | extinction = | merger = | merged = | established = {{Start date and age|1992 }} | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region_served = | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = Director | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[Jesuit]], [[Catholic church|Catholic]] | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [http://nyumbani.org Nyumbani] | remarks = }} [[File:Nyumbani.png|right|270px]]
'''The Nyumbani Children's Home''' was founded by Father Angelo D'Agostino and Sister Mary Owens in 1992 to serve mostly [[Child abandonment|abandoned children]] created by the [[AIDS]] [[pandemic]].<ref name=MakeAMark-OrphanageProfile-2010>{{cite news|title=Nyumbani Orphanage (Karen, Kenya): A "home" for Abandoned Children|url=http://www.makeamark.org/nyumbani.aspx|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=Make A Mark|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104115523/http://www.makeamark.org/nyumbani.aspx|archivedate=4 January 2010}}</ref> Since then, three more programs (Nyumbani Village, Lea Toto and Nyumbani Diagnostic Laboratory) have been added to the organization.
== Background == Originally a medical doctor in the US Air Force, D'Agostino joined the [[Jesuits]] early in his career, focused on psychiatry, and held various teaching positions. But it was through his experience working with multiple Jesuit charities that D'Agostino learned of the dire need for specialized facilities for abandoned children in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]]. Today over 100 orphans or abandoned children live at Nyumbani Children's Home located in [[Karen, Kenya|Karen]], Nairobi.<ref name=":0" />
In 1998, the recognition that there was a need to expand the basic initiative of Nyumbani Home to other locales gave birth to the Lea Toto program. This is "a community-based outreach program providing services to HIV+ children and their families in the Kangemi, Waithaka, Kawangware, Riruta, Mutuini, Ruthimitu, [[Kibera]] and [[Kariobangi]] communities of Nairobi, Kenya."<ref name=Nyumbani-LeaToto-2011>{{cite web|title=Lea Toto: The Need|url=http://www.nyumbani.org/lea_need.htm|website=Nyumbani|accessdate=23 September 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111208191530/http://www.nyumbani.org/lea_need.htm|archivedate=8 December 2011}}</ref> Nyumbani’s Lea Toto HIV/AIDS program operates eight centers and serves between 2,100 and 3,100 HIV-positive children and up to 15,000 family members every year.
In 2006, Nyumbani Village, which cares for over 1,000 children and 100 elderly grandparents, was established on 1,000 acres in Kitui County, Kenya.
The Nyumbani programs are supported by international boards the [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Ireland]], [[Spain]], [[Italy]] and [[Kenya]]. In addition to individual donations and corporate sponsorships, the executive boards around the world raise critical operating funds, provide expertise and much-needed volunteers.
== Nyumbani Village == Based on past success, a related effort called '''Nyumbani Village''' was spawned to support both orphans and elders impacted by the AIDS pandemic.<ref name=JNJ-NyumbaniVillage-2016>{{cite news|title=Welcome to Nyumbani: The Village That Gives a Home—and Hope—to Children With HIV|url=http://www.blogjnj.com/2016/09/nyumbani-village-home-for-children-with-hiv/|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Johnson & Johnson]]|date=21 September 2016}}</ref> Located on {{convert|1000|acre|km2}} donated by the [[Kitui District]] County Council, Nyumbani Village is conceived to support between 1280-1600 individuals via a self-sustaining agricultural based venture. Shortly after its inauguration, on 20 November 2006, Fr. D'Ag died. But with his organizational skills, this new venture also continued to prosper. In 2016 it had 120 employees tending to 100 elderly grandparents and 1000 children.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Children's Angel|last=Nese|first=Marco|work=Yearbook of the Society of Jesus: 2017|publisher=General Curia, Society of Jesus|year=2016|isbn=|location=Rome|pages=133–135}}</ref> In September 2016, actress [[Danai Gurira]] presented a video about the village and the work being done in Africa as part of the 2016 [[Global Citizen Festival]] in [[New York City]]<ref name=JNJ-IWasThere-Video-2016>{{cite web|last1=Gurira|first1=Danai|title=I Was There|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZg1I5pCABU|website=[[Johnson & Johnson]]|accessdate=23 September 2016|format=Video|date=19 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=People-Gurira-2016>{{cite news|last1=King|first1=Brittany|title=The Walking Dead's Danai Gurira: 'We Need a Helping Hand' for African Families Living with AIDS|url=http://www.people.com/article/walking-dead-danai-gurira-raising-awareness-aids-africa|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=23 September 2016}}</ref> and [[BBC]] has covered its learning curve in the use of drugs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-28372121|title=Caring for Kenya's HIV orphans|last=Soy|first=Anne|date=2014-07-21|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> The pharmaceuticals company [[Johnson & Johnson]] is a sponsoring partner via [[Global Citizen Festival|Global Citizen]], in an outreach effort to promote social action and awareness.<ref name=JNJ-Partner-Announcement-2016>{{cite news|last1=Elker|first1=Jessica|last2=Booth|first2=M|title=Johnson & Johnson Partners with Global Citizen to Improve the Trajectory of Human Health Around the World|url=http://www.jnj.com/news/all/Johnson-Johnson-Partners-with-Global-Citizen-to-Improve-the-Trajectory-of-Human-Health-Around-the-World|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Johnson & Johnson]]|date=7 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=JNJ-TakesAVillage-2016>{{cite news|last1=Sneed|first1=Michael|title=Why It Really Does Take a Village to Make the World a Healthier Place|url=http://www.blogjnj.com/2016/09/global-citizen-festival-and-johnson-johnson/|accessdate=23 September 2016|work=[[Johnson & Johnson]]|date=21 September 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Nairobi}} * {{URL|nyumbani.org|Nyumbani.org}} * [https://www.caringcrowd.org/protect-hiv-children-opportunistic-infections Protect HIV+ children from opportunistic infections] project at Caring Crowd – matching by [[Johnson & Johnson]] {{Authority control}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Per Villand | image = Per Villand.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date |1963|10|15}} | birth_place = Hovet, Norway | death_date = {{death date and age |2007|10|15 |1963|10|15}} | death_place = Hovet, Norway | resting_place_coordinates = {{coord|60.622786|8.157846|type:landmark|display=Hovet Church Cemetery}} | death_cause = Transition to [[end-of-life care]] in advanced [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] | citizenship = Norway | nationality = Norwegian | fields = | workplaces = {{plainlist| * [[University of Tromsø]] * [[Carnegie Institution for Science]] * [[Michigan State University]] * [[Umeå University]] }} | education = | alma_mater = {{plainlist| *[[University of Tromsø]] *[[Norwegian University of Life Sciences]] *[[Umeå University]] }} | known_for = Molecular Biology; Microbiology Patents; Plant Science; Co-researcher ALS disease; Documentary: "Eit meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp – Å leve med Amyotrofisk lateral sklerose (ALS)"; local history writing }} '''Per Villand''' ([[Hovet, Buskerud]], 15 October 1963 – 15 October 2007) was a Norwegian molecular biologist,<ref name= "Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Doctor Scientiarum Degree, Molecular Plant Biology, 28 September 1995">{{cite web|url=https://www.edocr.com/v/gyqn9wwg/norskedokumenter/Doctor-Scientiarum-degree-1995-Per-Villand|title=Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Doctor Scientiarum Degree, Molecular Plant Biology, 28 September 1995|website=Edocr|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref> who contributed to a further development of molecular plant science<ref name= "Carnegie Institution for Science">{{cite journal|url=http://www.cell.com/trends/plant-science/comments/S1360-1385(98)01354-5|title=Dept of Plant Biology, Carnegie Institution of Washington, Stanford, CA 94305, USA|website=CellPress|accessdate=2017-10-24|doi=10.1016/S1360-1385(98)01354-5|volume=4|year=1999|pages=38–41 | last1 = Kehoe | first1 = David M. | last2 = Villand | first2 = Per | last3 = Somerville | first3 = Shauna}}</ref><ref name= "Umeå University">{{cite journal|title=Carbon dioxide and light regulation of promoters controlling the expression of mitochondrial carbonic anhydrase in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, Department of Plant Physiology, Umeå University, S-901 87 Umeå, Sweden.| pmid=9355734 | volume=327 | pmc=1218762| issue=1| year=1997| journal=Biochem J| pages=51–7 | last1 = Villand | first1 = P | last2 = Eriksson | first2 = M | last3 = Samuelsson | first3 = G}}</ref><ref name= "Umeå">{{cite journal|title=Induction and Regulation of Expression of a Low-CO2-Induced Mitochondrial Carbonic Anhydrase in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, Department of Plant Physiology, Umeâ University, 901 87 Umeâ, Sweden|website=National US Library of Medicine|pmc=35121 | pmid=9490764|volume=116|year=1998|pages=637–41 | last1 = Eriksson | first1 = M | last2 = Villand | first2 = P | last3 = Gardeström | first3 = P | last4 = Samuelsson | first4 = G}}</ref> until 1999, when he was diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]]. During his illness he assisted medical professionals to research ALS, and developed, together with [[Lillehammer University College]]<ref name= "A meaningful life in a paralytic body">{{cite web|url=http://websok.mikromarc.no/Mikromarc3/Web/detail.aspx?Unit=6464&db=assiden-vgs&Id=15726&SW=Sykdommer&SC=EM&LB=TI&MT=7&SU=6471&DG=&ST=Normal&Browse=1|website=Mikromarc|title=A meaningful life in a paralytic body|accessdate=2017-10-23}}</ref><ref name= "Documentary by the Lillehammer University College">{{cite web|url=https://extrastiftelsen.no/prosjekter/meningsfylt-liv-i-en-lam-kropp/|title=Meningsfylt liv i en lam kropp|website=Extra Stiftelsen|accessdate=2017-10-30}}</ref>, his own idea to create the documentary: "A meaningful life in a paralytic body ~ Living with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis", which was produced and released in 2005. He died on October 15, 2007, at the age of 44.<ref name="So dagane går / As days go by, Sigmund Krøvel-Velle">{{cite web|url=https://www.edocr.com/v/na9wl4en/norskedokumenter/Hallingdolen-Som-dagane-gar-15-10-2013|title=So dagane går / As days go by, Sigmund Krøvel-Velle|website=Edocr|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref>
==Studies== At the [[University of Tromsø]], Per Villand was Candidatus Magisterii in biology from 1985–1987, was Candidatus Scientiarum in [[Molecular Biology]] from 1988–1989 and received his [[Cand.scient.]] degree<ref name= "Candidatus Scientiarum degree">{{cite web|url=https://www.edocr.com/v/zpqljpa2/norskedokumenter/Candidatus-Scientiarum-degree-1990-Per-Villand|title=Confirmation of Candidatus Scientiarum degree of Per Villand|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref><ref name= "Thesis Cand. Scient. degree">{{cite web|url=http://jvi.asm.org/content/64/8/3864.long|title=Thesis Cand. Scient. degree: At Least Two Types of Control Regions Can Be Found among Naturally Occurring BK Virus Strains|website=Journal of Virology, American Society for Microbiology|accessdate=2017-10-26}}</ref> in 1990. In 1990 he worked as a staff engineer at the Department of Cell Biology of the [[University of Tromsø]]. At the [[Norwegian University of Life Sciences]] Per Villand was studying for the title Doctor Scientiarum in Molecular Plant Biology from 1990–1995. He received the title Doctor Scientiarum, or [[Dr.scient.]], a Norwegian term for [[Doctor of Science]], at the [[Norwegian University of Life Sciences]] in 1995.<ref name= "Doctor Scientiarum degree">{{cite web|url=https://www.edocr.com/v/gyqn9wwg/norskedokumenter/Doctor-Scientiarum-degree-1995-Per-Villand|website=Edocr|title=Doctor Scientiarum Degree, Molecular Plant Biology, 28 September 1995|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref>
==Scientific accomplishments== Per Villand contributed to the advancing of molecular plant science. He participated in international teams of investigators at the University of Tromsø in Norway, the Michigan State University in USA, the Umeå University in Sweden, and the department of Plant Biology of the Carnegie Institution for Science, Stanford, CA, USA. As a [[postdoctoral researcher]] he worked from 1995–1997 at [[Umeå University]] in Sweden and from 1998–1999 he researched [[plant science]] at the department of Plant Biology of the [[Carnegie Institution for Science]], Stanford, CA, USA. From 1999–2000 he was Research Assistant at the [[Umeå University]]<ref name= "Per Villand's scientific contributions, Umeå University and other institutions">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/39577407_Per_Villand|title=Per Villand's scientific contributions, Umeå University and other institutions|website=ResearchGate|accessdate=2017-12-05}}</ref><ref name="Department of Plant Physiology, Umeå University">{{cite web|url=http://www.plantphysiol.org/content/plantphysiol/116/2/637.full.pdf|title=Department of Plant Physiology, Umeå University|website=PlantPhysiol|accessdate=2017-12-07}}</ref>, in [[Sweden]].
He received a [[patent]] for ''Transgenic organism''<ref name= "Transgenic Organism">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.no/patents/WO1994024292A2?cl=en&dq=ininventor:Per+ininventor:Villand&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzp5j20pLXAhWlYZoKHXGhDbkQ6AEIJzAA|title=Patent: Transgenic Organism|website=Patents|accessdate=2017-10-28}}</ref> and for ''Transgenic plants or algae expressing an AGP enzyme coupled to a transit peptide''<ref name= "Patent: Transgenic plants or algae expressing an AGP enzyme coupled to a transit peptide,">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.no/patents/US5977437?dq=ininventor:Per+ininventor:Villand&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzp5j20pLXAhWlYZoKHXGhDbkQ6AEILjAB|title=Transgenic plants or algae expressing an AGP enzyme coupled to a transit peptide|website=Patent|accessdate=2017-10-28}}</ref> When in 1999 amyotrophic lateral sclerosis was diagnosed he researched this disease, together with medical professionals, till he passed away on October 15, 2007, because of the transition to [[end-of-life care]] in the terminal phase of the disease.
==Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis== In 1999 Per Villand was diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]]. At the end of 2005 he was paralysed for 90%: only the eye muscles were not affected. After planning the transition to [[end-of-life care]] in the terminal phase of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, he passed away on his birthday, October 15, 2007.
===Documentary=== In the [[documentary]] "Eit meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp – Å leve med Amyotrofisk lateral sklerose (ALS)" / A meaningful life in a paralytic body – Living with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]]<ref name= "Eit meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp">{{cite web|url=http://websok.mikromarc.no/Mikromarc3/Web/detail.aspx?Unit=6464&db=assiden-vgs&Id=15726&SW=Sykdommer&SC=EM&LB=TI&MT=7&SU=6471&DG=&ST=Normal&Browse=1|title=Eit Meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp : å leve med amyotrofisk lateral sklerose (ALS)|website=Mikromarc websearch|accessdate=2017-10-23}}</ref><ref name= "Film documentary">{{cite web|url=https://extrastiftelsen.no/prosjekter/meningsfylt-liv-i-en-lam-kropp/|title=Meningsfylt liv i en lam kropp|website=Extra Stiftelsen|accessdate=2017-10-23}}</ref><ref name= "Cover of the DVD">{{cite web|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A_meaningful_life_in_a_paralytic_body_-_Living_with_Amyotrophic_Lateral_Sclerosis_(ALS).png|title=Cover of the DVD|website=Wikimedia Commons|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref> Per Villand shares his experiences and thoughts about his illness in several different topics. Nurses, doctors, relatives and other involved, contribute with information and comments. * Idea: Per Villand; Mette Villand-Reichelt * Producer: [[Lillehammer University College]]<ref name="Lillehammer University College">{{cite web|url=http://hil.no/eng|title=Senter for livslang læring|website=Inland Norway University of Applied Sciences|accessdate=2017-10-26}}</ref>, Norway * Script: Per Villand * Director, editor and narrator: Ingrid Ese Folkestad * Project manager: Kjell Are Refsvik * Music: (1) Helge Lilletvedt, [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] – Cantata No. 170 – [[Vergnügte Ruh, beliebte Seelenlust, BWV 170]] / "Delightful rest, beloved pleasure of the soul" (2) [[Janet Baker]], [[mezzo-soprano]], [[Philip Ledger]] (organ), [[Academy of St Martin in the Fields]], [[Neville Marriner]], Decca 1991 – [[Bach Cantata]] (3) [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]: [[Goldberg variations]] – [[Aria]], [[Keith Jarrett]], ECM records 1989 (4) [[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Shostakovich)]] [[New York Philharmonic]], [[Leonard Bernstein]], CBS Records Inc., 1988 * Audio engineer: Stein Tore Sønsteli * Graphic design: Kjell Are Refsvik The documentary creates awareness about the vulnerable position of people with disabilities in the society, and is categorized as visual education for people with disabilities, for professionals in healthcare, but also for the family and friends around people with disabilities. Total playing time: 05:42:50. The DVD is available in Geilo Bibliotek, in Hol, and in Lillehammer Bibliotek.
===Book=== During his illness Per Villand was able to communicate and write by means of an eye-tracker and a computer.<ref name= "Assistive Devices for People with Hearing, Voice, Speech, or Language Disorders">{{cite web|url=https://www.nidcd.nih.gov/health/assistive-devices-people-hearing-voice-speech-or-language-disorders|title=Eye-tracker|website=U.S. Department of Health & Human Services|accessdate=2017-10-28}}</ref> In this way he could write a book of 300 pages (gallery) and build a website<ref name= "History of Søre Villand and Raggsteindalen">{{cite web|url=http://villand.net/|title=History of Søre Villand and Raggsteindalen|website=Velkommen til Villand|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref> about two historical locations, named Søre Villand and Raggsteindalen, in the traditional district of [[Hallingdal]]. <gallery> Stall Sore Villand 1700-tallet (1).jpg|Stable from Søre Villand, Hovet, Norway. Built in the later 1700s, purchased by the museum in 1918, taken down in 1919 and resurrected at Marienlyst in 1922. Per Villandː HIstory of "Søre Villand" and "Raggsteindalen".png|The book: "Søre Villand og Raggsteindalen 1889-2005 : slekta, garden og turisthytta", written by Per Villand, published on October 14, 2007. Stall Sore Villand 1700-tallet (2).jpg|Stable from Søre Villand, Hovet, Norway. Built in the later 1700s, purchased by the museum in 1918, taken down in 1919 and resurrected at Marienlyst in 1922. </gallery>
==See also== * ''Discussion about ALS'': Narkive – [http://no.fag.medisin.diverse.narkive.com/Lh3kHQ2x/als Per Villand / Posts by: Jon Lie, Jon Haugsand]
==External links== * ''Per Villand'': [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=P.+VILLAND Scholar] (list with publications) * ''PubMed'': US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health / Per Villand: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Villand%20P%5BAuthor%5D&cauthor=true&cauthor_uid=9490764 Summary] * ''WorldCat'': List of articles in which [https://www.worldcat.org/search?qt=worldcat_org_all&q=Per+Villand Per Villand participated in international teams of investigators] * ''Google Patents'': [https://www.google.no/patents/WO1994024292A2?cl=en&dq=ininventor:Per+ininventor:Villand&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzp5j20pLXAhWlYZoKHXGhDbkQ6AEIJzAA Transgenic organism], [https://www.google.no/patents/US5977437?dq=ininventor:Per+ininventor:Villand&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzp5j20pLXAhWlYZoKHXGhDbkQ6AEILjAB Transgenic plants or algae expressing an AGP enzyme coupled to a transit peptide] * ''VIAF'', Virtual International Authority File: [http://viaf.org/viaf/78149366414385602854/#Villand,_Per Per Villand] * ''ResearchGate'': Per Villand, [https://www.researchgate.net/search/publications?q=Per%2BVilland publications] * ''Trends in plant science'': David M. Kehoe, Per Villand, Shauna Somerville: [http://www.cell.com/trends/plant-science/comments/S1360-1385(98)01354-5 DNA microarrays for studies of higher plants and other photosynthetic organisms] * ''American Society of Plant Biologists'': Mats Eriksson, Per Villand, Per Gardeström, and Göran Samuelsson: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC35121/ Induction and Regulation of Expression of a Low-CO2-Induced Mitochondrial Carbonic Anhydrase in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii] * ''American Society of Plant Biologists'': Per Villand, Odd-Arne Olsen, Andrzej Kilian, and Leszek A. Kleczkowski: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1075837/ ADP-Glucose Pyrophosphorylase Large Subunit cDNA from Barley Endosperm] * ''Portland Press'': Per Villand, Mats Eriksson, Göran Samuelsson: [http://www.biochemj.org/content/327/1/51 Carbon dioxide and light regulation of promoters controlling the expression of mitochondrial carbonic anhydrase in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii] * ''Plant Molecular Biology'': Per Villand, Reidunn Aalen, Odd-Arne Olsen, Ernst Lüthi, Anders Lönneborg, Leszek A. Kleczkowski: [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00023385 PCR amplification and sequences of cDNA clones for the small and large subunits of ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase from barley tissues] * ''Dagbladet'': Per Villand: [https://www.dagbladet.no/kultur/genteknologi-og-frykt/65428891 Genteknologi og frykt]
==Further reading== * ''Biography Per Villand'': [http://websok.mikromarc.no/Mikromarc3/web/detail.aspx?Unit=41499&db=hallingdal-felles&Id=76327&SW=Per%20Villand&SC=FT&LB=FT&MT=0&SU=38027&DG=0&ST=Normal&Browse=1&P=1 Søre Villand og Ragsteindalen], 1889–2005, page 251, 252. Library of Geilo, Hol municipality, Norway. * ''Edocr'': Per Villand, biography<ref name= "Per Villand, biography">{{cite web|url=https://www.edocr.com/v/x80oy2ex/norskedokumenter/Biografi-Per-Villand|title=Per Villand, biography|website=Edocr|accessdate=2017-11-04}}</ref> * ''Kåre Olav Solhjell'': Hol i Hundre År<ref name= "Cover of the book">{{cite web|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:K%C3%A5re_Olav_Solhjell%CB%90_Hol_i_Hundre_%C3%85r.png|title=Cover of the book|website=Wikimedia Commons|accessdate=2017-11-26}}</ref>, p. 485 ~ Trykk: 07-Gruppen, Oslo ~ {{ISBN|978-82-995751-4-0}} * ''Elise Reitan Gilberg'': Bachelor thesis on nursing: "[https://brage.bibsys.no/xmlui/handle/11250/95802 Håpet bryter igjennom mørket]" * ''Library Geilo'': the educational DVD [http://websok.mikromarc.no/Mikromarc3/web/detail.aspx?Unit=41499&db=hallingdal-felles&Id=70610&SW=Per%20Villand&SC=FT&LB=FT&MT=0&SU=38027&DG=0&ST=Normal&Browse=1&P=1 Eit Meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp : å leve med amyotrofisk lateral sklerose (ALS)] * ''Library Lillehammer'': the educational DVD [http://www.lillehammer.folkebibl.no/cmsms/tittel/352410/Eit-meiningsfylt-liv-i-ein-lam-kropp/ Eit meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp]. Category professional literature * ''edocr'': text in Norwegian, and an English translation, of the [https://www.edocr.com/v/pmaden2p/norskedokumenter/Norway-documentary-Eit-meiningsfylt-liv-i-ein-lam- back cover of the DVD] Eit meiningsfylt liv i ein lam kropp: å leve med amyotrofisk lateral sklerose (ALS) * ''Norwegian Association For Palliative Medicine'': [http://legeforeningen.no/PageFiles/44297/Standard_for_palliative_care_ENGLISH.pdf Standard for Palliative Care, NFPM 2004]
